Unable to freeze job graph: Decryption failed.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2020-02-14 02:57:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

My thinking is still very fluid on this, but I've come up with what I really hope is a good alternative?

It starts from the thought that every platform we care about has python3 and venv (even centos7 now).  In our previous discussions we all agreed that we do not care what things like glean and bindep are installed with during the build, as long as they are there.

So, my general thought is that we can ship all our images completely devoid of any non-distro-packaged python components.  That's what the following two changes implement:

 https://review.opendev.org/707513 dib: Add ensure-venv element, install glean with it
 https://review.opendev.org/707750 project-config: nodepool-elements: Use venv for utilities

Very importantly, we still need the work in this change to create a backwards compatible environment for existing tests that looks like what pip-and-virtualenv provided ... but I feel that should be part of the base jobs.

I think this is win/win:

 * for people who want plain images with nothing non-distro installed, they can avoid that part of the base jobs
 * we can do backwards compat in jobs -- which means if something screws up (and it *always* does with the pip/virtualenv/setuptools combo), we fix the job and get gate testing and instant deployment (no need to rebuild images or release dib).
 * for initial deployment, we can validate it: create new images devoid of pip/virtualenv as a temporary node type, and we can run the backwards compat jobs on just them to get us more confident. 

With this, what I worry this has dropped is one of the biggest pain points for everyone which is the package pinning (both dib, trying to implement it, and others, who don't want it).  It seems to me like we've installed pip and virtualenv (04-install-pip) but we've also marked the packages as uninstalled (package-installs.yaml).  The problem in the past has been that jobs depend on things that pull those packages back in, and everything gets in a big mess.  ergo the package pins to avoid this."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-02-14 15:59:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Aha - yes - I think that's a good plan. In fact, it might allow more jobs, like maybe the devstack base job, to not run this code but instead to run their own (like, I think devstack already has support for using cached get-pip script to install pip)

So really what we'd probably want to do with a zuul-jobs ensure-pip role is put it in unittests - and then probably legacy-base.

Also - another thing to maybe consider trying - seeing if we can pip install tox ... and then pip uninstall tox and all of its depends - so that we get a primed /root/.pip/cache. That way we could have ensure-tox just pip install tox, but it wouldn't be that big of a hit because we'd already have all the wheels downloaded in ~/.pip/cache. Yeah?

I like where you're going with this."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-12 23:23:51.000000000', 'message': "Add simple-pip element

We have two diametrically opposed use cases amongst our user base.

The first are the folks who just need tox/virtualenv to pre-exist,
so that they can do things like run tests. Neither tox nor virtualenv
themselves are fundamental to the thing under test, but are tools
that need to exist.

The second are folks for whom tools like pip or virtualenv are
essential to the software (such as OSA). For these users, it is
important that the version of those match what they expect their
users get from the distro.

Up until now, we've been using the pip-and-virtualenv element from
DIB which installs distro versions of pip and virtualenv, then
overwrites them with pip installed versions of the same, doing what
it can to prevent subsequent distro installs of the packages from
breaking things. This produces a really strange environment for
our friends in teh second camp, but honestly is a weird scenarios
to wrap the head around.

Instead, remove ALL distro packages of pip and virtualenv. Then
install both via get-pip. We can't do that on Centos7 for python3,
but that's ok, because get-pip installs into /usr/local in that
case.

Leave a cleanup script. Modern pip can uninstall stuff, including
itself. So uninstall the things that we install.  This cleanup
script can be run by folks like OSA in their first pre-playbook
in zuul, and then their jobs can subsequently apt-get or dnf
install python3-virtualenv or whatever they want to do that is
appropriate.

Change-Id: I627c5d4df12712f87a9cb4f98faa8ff0f0b78d9d

commit_message:
Add get-pip element

We have two diametrically opposed use cases amongst our user base.

The first are the folks who just need tox/virtualenv to pre-exist,
so that they can do things like run tests. Neither tox nor virtualenv
themselves are fundamental to the thing under test, but are tools
that need to exist.

The second are folks for whom tools like pip or virtualenv are
essential to the software (such as OSA). For these users, it is
important that the version of those match what they expect their
users get from the distro.

Up until now, we've been using the pip-and-virtualenv element from
DIB which installs distro versions of pip and virtualenv, then
overwrites them with pip installed versions of the same, doing what
it can to prevent subsequent distro installs of the packages from
breaking things. This produces a really strange environment for
our friends in teh second camp, but honestly is a weird scenarios
to wrap the head around.

Instead, remove ALL distro packages of pip and virtualenv. Then
install both via get-pip. We can't do that on Centos7 for python3,
but that's ok, because get-pip installs into /usr/local in that
case.

Leave a cleanup script. Modern pip can uninstall stuff, including
itself. So uninstall the things that we install.  This cleanup
script can be run by folks like OSA in their first pre-playbook
in zuul, and then their jobs can subsequently apt-get or dnf
install python3-virtualenv or whatever they want to do that is
appropriate.

Change-Id: I627c5d4df12712f87a9cb4f98faa8ff0f0b78d9d

commit_message:
Allow specified http ports to be ignored by packetbeat

Packetbeat monitors traffic for all http ports specified for heartbeat
services. This change provides an additional list of ports to ignore
to filter traffic at source e.g. that generated by Elasticsearch,
Kibana & Logstash itself.

Change-Id: I57ac8582c4cc8a6fe5826fdbffbac4ab4e98ac78

commit_message:
Fix Cinder Backup access to kernel modules (iscsi_tcp issue)

It looks like the only missing part was the actual mount of
/lib/modules

Now Cinder Backup volumes differ from Cinder Volume volumes only
by /etc/target which is not relevant (Cinder Backup does not
provide a target).

Change-Id: Iccf4298c4f9306eb0a95b6712815778555ef44fc
Closes-bug: #1863094

commit_message:
Set show_diff to false for auth_file

We should not show changes in output since
the password might be leaked there.

I will add a follow-up patch later in master
that cleans up testing and etc.

We need to backport this to all versions.

Change-Id: Ief909c8303d7d29dcd0c19ee4cb4974667eadbcb
(cherry picked from commit 1c072a304ea9a5f791223d617ed2a49754690903)

commit_message:
Set show_diff to false for auth_file

We should not show changes in output since
the password might be leaked there.

I will add a follow-up patch later in master
that cleans up testing and etc.

We need to backport this to all versions.

Change-Id: Ief909c8303d7d29dcd0c19ee4cb4974667eadbcb
(cherry picked from commit 1c072a304ea9a5f791223d617ed2a49754690903)

[{'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-10-30 21:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-30 21:32:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For awareness, this was in the mailing list (quite a bit) during the spec review:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-April/thread.html#116028

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-May/thread.html#116133'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-10-30 21:40:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To be clear (Blark/ Sam), this came up in IRC a few minutes ago so Eric threw it up for discussion.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2019-10-30 21:47:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

In at least one Edge deployment model, compute nodes at an edge site would be coerced to use a local (to that site) glance-api service, with the main glance endpoint residing in the control plane (e.g. some data center).

Can this architecture be supported without the ability to override the glance servers?'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-10-30 21:50:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build SUCCESSFUL (check pipeline).

- pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered http://52.27.155.124/27/692227/1/check/pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered/f516660/ : SUCCESS in 27m 56s'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-10-30 22:25:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-38672 : SUCCESS in 1h 03m 16s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-10-30 22:27:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> In at least one Edge deployment model, compute nodes at an edge site would be coerced to use a local (to that site) glance-api service, with the main glance endpoint residing in the control plane (e.g. some data center).
> 
> Can this architecture be supported without the ability to override the glance servers?

I don't fully understand your explanation, so apologies if I answer the wrong thing.

With the standard ksa config options, you can still ignore the service catalog and provide an ``endpoint_override``. The only thing api_servers gives you is the ability to specify *multiple* endpoints and have nova cycle through them from one API call to the next."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-10-30 23:05:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

In general, API consumers talk to OpenStack services by getting the service endpoint from the keystone catalog, and then talking to "the endpoint" for that service. The idea behind all of this is that Nova should talk to other services like a normal API consumer, not like a special API consumer that does weird things.

In a cloud where there are multiple glance API servers - there would *have* to be a load balancer so that they can be put into the catalog so that API consumers who are not Nova can talk to them. (things like Ansible, or Salt or python-openstackclient or Terraform)

Alan - yes, as efried says, you can absolutely override "the endpoint" for a service via config.'}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-10-30 23:13:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Fine with this as long as there is another way top specify a specific glance server? In a large environment with multiple data centres we want to point the nova-compute to the closest glance. 

(we currently have around 20 glance-api servers across two countries that aren't the glance servers in the catalog and only serve nova-computes)"}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-10-30 23:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

No I fully read the comments and I see it is possible :-)'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2019-10-30 23:21:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, so it seems an endpoint override is how cases like Edge can work. Multiple glance-api nodes will likely be deployed at each Edge site (for HA), and I guess it will require a loadbalancer, etc. to provide the endpoint for that site.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-10-30 23:56:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-30 21:21:26.000000000', 'message': "Deprecate [glance]api_servers

When adding support for standard ksa config options in Queens [1], we
retained the [glance]api_servers option in case consumers wanted to
continue to rely on nova's rudimentary load balancing rather than
implementing something real. Continuing to support this option is
holding us back from the things that having a common standard across
services would facilitate, like using openstacksdk rather than clients.
So deprecate it.

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/use-ksa-adapter-for-endpoints.html

Change-Id: I8e3fbc6f8b052ead6e80d4243f76581960210277
"}]
commit_message:
Deprecate [glance]api_servers

When adding support for standard ksa config options in Queens [1], we
retained the [glance]api_servers option in case consumers wanted to
continue to rely on nova's rudimentary load balancing rather than
implementing something real. Continuing to support this option is
holding us back from the things that having a common standard across
services would facilitate, like using openstacksdk rather than clients.
So deprecate it.

[1] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/use-ksa-adapter-for-endpoints.html

Change-Id: I8e3fbc6f8b052ead6e80d4243f76581960210277

commit_message:
Added ``bus`` attribute to PhysicalDisks for NVMe drives

This patch adds `bus` attribute to PhysicalDisks so clients
can determine the PCI bus ID of NVMe drives.

Change-Id: I9b6b88826b9902a059e1bf537e51d9f97c9389ba

commit_message:
Remove kolla Ceph container images

This change removes ceph* Dockerfiles and relevant kolla python
code bits.

Kolla-Ansible part has been removed, and K-A was the only consumer.

Change-Id: I9568261fdbbe4b9156d0e07c414ec911ca2e8557

commit_message:
Enable stack status output for tripleo deploy

At somewhere along the line, we lost the heat stack status output
indicating what progress was being made while waiting for a stack to
build. This change sets verbosity to True for the tripleo deploy command
so that the output is always shown.

Closes-Bug: #1862188

Change-Id: Id349dbc8a554c2fa542b986062e708bbc14da714
(cherry picked from commit 76bbb37984cfda623823f51b0be8a33b79afa21c)

commit_message:
Merge networking-ovn documentation into neutron

It also adds 2 sample of devstack's local.conf file
for deploying Neutron with OVN mechanism driver.

Needed to create PNG files out of the existing SVG
ones in order to pass the pdf doc build.

commit_message:
Support query queues with count

Zaqar will support query queues with '--with_count' to
return the amount of the queues. This will help users to
quickly get the exact total number of queues which they own.

Change-Id: Iced54e7d270e389a23db2a19394025710565923d
Implements: blueprint query-queues-with-count
Signed-off-by: wanghao <sxmatch1986@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Allow ceph metal CI deployments

eth1 interface is not a valid interface for metal deployments.
br-mgmt interface should be used instead as a `monitor_interface`.

Change-Id: I8310c2485f2bfb9b283068d43c8acd35f29197c3

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 17:11:13.000000000', 'message': 'Set an absolute path in rootwrap filters_path

If a relative path is set in rootwrap filters_path, the rootwrap
command must be executed from the neutron root directory. Some
commands, like those execute by RootHelperProcess, do not have
a defined working directory. To avoid the problems present in the
related bug, an absolute path is set in the rootwrap configuration.

Related-Bug: #1862927

Change-Id: I02ce4d6b84242c42ec26954eeb9b776cb779bff4
'}]
commit_message:
Set an absolute path in rootwrap filters_path

If a relative path is set in rootwrap filters_path, the rootwrap
command must be executed from the neutron root directory. Some
commands, like those execute by RootHelperProcess, do not have
a defined working directory. To avoid the problems present in the
related bug, an absolute path is set in the rootwrap configuration.

Related-Bug: #1862927

Change-Id: I02ce4d6b84242c42ec26954eeb9b776cb779bff4

(cherry picked from commit d8fbf04f325f593836f8d44b6bbf42b85bde94e3)
'}]
commit_message:
Mask the token used to allow access to consoles

Hide the novncproxy token from the logs.

When backported this patch needs to be extended to handle the same issue
in the consoleauth service.

Co-Authored-By:paul-carlton2 <paul.carlton2@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By:Tristan Cacqueray <tdecacqu@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5b8fa4233d297722c3af08176901d12887bae3de
Closes-Bug: #1492140
(cherry picked from commit 26d4047e17eba9bc271f8868f1d0ffeec97b555e)
(cherry picked from commit d7826bcd761af035f3f76f67c607dde2a1d04e48)
(cherry picked from commit d8fbf04f325f593836f8d44b6bbf42b85bde94e3)

commit_message:
Rework rally-install-* jobs

* use python3
* do not use install_rally.sh script
* check centos-8
* remove postgres packages brom bindep

Change-Id: I00abce40d333352b25848cfe941f845746bffa8c

[{'created': '2020-02-12 10:17:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add dependency for enable KSM for RHEL/CentOS8

With the OS change to version 8, the qemu-kvm-common package
name changed to just qemu-kvm-common instead of qemu-kvm-common-ev
or qemu-kvm-common-rhev. This adds a condition for the major
OS version.

Change-Id: Idd69c687232a10fcb6db79a8b835a1576b7558dd
Closes-Bug: #1862921
'}]
commit_message:
Add dependency for enable KSM for RHEL/CentOS8

With the OS change to version 8, the qemu-kvm-common package
name changed to just qemu-kvm-common instead of qemu-kvm-common-ev
or qemu-kvm-common-rhev. This adds a condition for the major
OS version.

Change-Id: Idd69c687232a10fcb6db79a8b835a1576b7558dd
Closes-Bug: #1862921

commit_message:
[update] Ensure we get fresh hiera data before running update_steps.

We need to make sure that the hiera data are fresh before the update
step so that anyone using those data during those steps are seeing the
latest information from heat.

Factor out the hiera generation and include it in deployment and
update playbooks.

The double tasks definition in the deployment playbook seemed to be
redundant so It has been removed.

Change-Id: I6b6c676880ccc8cbed23af135e5865c222a8f1d0
Closes-Bug: #1861799

commit_message:
Let the daemonset file use all new parameters generated by the overrides.

Move the $daemonset_yaml parameter in the daemonset
file to the overrides file, so that daemonset file
uses parameters after overrides.

Change-Id: I9e71c31b1139bceafd653531e21ce527a8deb985
Story: 2007291
Task: 38754
Signed-off-by: songgongjun <gongjun.song@intel.com>

commit_message:
Use become for kill command

Cherry-picked commit d4734437b[1] introduces a regression that
non-privileged user deployment fails. Because Kill command requires
privilege to run.

[1]: d4734437b Fix nova scheduler down after first docker restart

Change-Id: Ic3292fe00742f7719d379b6ac4a023dc8b050700

[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 17:43:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:00:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:13:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(14 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:22:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:25:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Overall I really like this idea. I agree that we  have a number of periodic tasks/healing activities that are "central" and don't really fit in any one service today. And I have heard throughout the years from operators that it would be ideal if nova could automatically heal itself in any situation where it's possible. It would save them a lot of time and effort.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:38:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:41:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:46:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:52:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-06 18:56:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-07 13:02:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Adding cdent because he's mentioned a few times the need/desire for what the ResourceTracker used to do regarding automatically writing allocations. The heal_allocations command is obviously different from that since the RT would overwrite allocations created by the scheduler (starting in Pike) which was a split brain problem for migrations, which is why we then did migration-based allocations in Queens. Having something periodically running heal_allocations that the operator doesn't have to setup an explicit cron for though should help in the cases that allocations are lost for an instance and we just want to automatically heal them back based on the flavor (and ports if there are qos ports attached with resource allocation requests)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-07 13:20:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

I'm cool with this except for the part about deprecating and moving the existing nova-manage commands. More detailed thoughts within.

Also, I think this could likely move forward without that if it becomes a sticking point."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-07 13:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-11-07 13:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)

Overall I think this is a great idea. I think are details on the architecture and implementation that can be debated, but the general idea of "fixing stuff that has to be fixed, that we know how to fix, automatically" is really good.

One caveat on that is we'll want to be conscious about not allowing the presence of this fixer to let things that break be sloppy. The justification of "it's a distributed system" is true, but at least some of those common breakages are the result of bugs that we don't want to always mask. So it might makes sense that the tool report on the perceived health: "I had to do task X for N instances Z times in the last M days, you're sick!"

I also wonder whether we shouldn't do more to allow the nova-compute process correct placement on its own. I guess it can't be fully authoritative (in isolation) about the state of migrations, so that's perhaps a non-starter, but I've always felt a bit awkward about the need to construct a representation of reality from several physical places.

I guess that's why it's called virtualization...

Anyway: yes, please do this.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-07 14:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)

> One caveat on that is we'll want to be conscious about not allowing
 > the presence of this fixer to let things that break be sloppy. The
 > justification of "it's a distributed system" is true, but at least
 > some of those common breakages are the result of bugs that we don't
 > want to always mask. So it might makes sense that the tool report
 > on the perceived health: "I had to do task X for N instances Z
 > times in the last M days, you're sick!"

For sure. I think that this can log all kinds of things at info level, but any healing gets logged as ERROR or WARNING. Operators would, if they run this as a daemon, digest those logs as well and not ignore ERROR any more than they normally would.

 > I also wonder whether we shouldn't do more to allow the
 > nova-compute process correct placement on its own. I guess it can't
 > be fully authoritative (in isolation) about the state of
 > migrations, so that's perhaps a non-starter, but I've always felt a
 > bit awkward about the need to construct a representation of reality
 > from several physical places.

Well, that's a different topic somewhat, as (a) many of the things here are not placement related, definitely not suitable for computes to be doing, and not really something you want all conductors doing all the time. And (b) as you say, computes healing with their isolated view of the world leads to other problems which is why we've tended away from that activity lately. It seems like the right thing to do, but there are devilish details.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-07 15:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-07 15:50:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-07 18:06:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-07 18:07:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-11 19:14:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

I like the general motive and concept.  This is useful for deployments.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-11 20:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I like the general motive and concept.  This is useful for deployments.

How do you feel about deprecating the nova-manage commands that would be used by the audit command and eventually moving those to the audit command? Would you want that or not care?'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-20 17:40:12.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-23 21:14:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> > I like the general motive and concept.  This is useful for
 > deployments.
 > 
 > How do you feel about deprecating the nova-manage commands that
 > would be used by the audit command and eventually moving those to
 > the audit command? Would you want that or not care?

I'd prefer a service that just keeps stuff running properly all the time."}, {'account_id': 9452, 'date': '2019-11-25 20:40:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> > I like the general motive and concept.  This is useful for
 > deployments.
 > 
 > How do you feel about deprecating the nova-manage commands that
 > would be used by the audit command and eventually moving those to
 > the audit command? Would you want that or not care?

Deprecating nova-manage makes sense to me. I'd rather have this in a service repairing everything on the fly."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-25 21:58:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Deprecating nova-manage makes sense to me. I'd rather have this in a service repairing everything on the fly.

The spec isn't proposing that certain nova-manage commands would just be deprecated and eventually removed and replaced by this nova-audit service. It's saying the nova-manage commands in question would be deprecated and moved to the nova-audit command which could also be run in daemon mode, but the commands themselves wouldn't be removed so you still have a way to run them on-demand as needed."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-26 22:43:36.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

Restoring as a multi-person effort.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-26 22:57:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

OK, I emailed a set of operators for a sanity check with Dan and Matt cc'ed and got responses from eandersson and mnaser expressing a +1 for the idea and no qualms with deprecating/removing the nova-manage commands and moving them to the nova-audit command. And we also have a comment of support from penick on here (posted while in Abandoned state, so +1 wasn't available) and again no qualms with moving the commands out of nova-manage and into nova-audit.

I have been +2 on this idea and think it's the right thing to do. I think there is significant need for automatic healing/cleaning functionality to be available in nova and a cleanup of the nova-manage alongside it makes sense. Nova-manage has been a dumping ground for lots of commands and I think it would be beneficial to move the healing/cleaning ones out into their own proper home.

My only personal hesitation with this proposal was with operators potentially balking at the idea of moving the nova-manage commands. Based on the operator responses to my email, I now feel comfortable that operators will not mind the move aspect of it.

With the command deprecation and move confirmed not to be a problem with operators, I vote +2."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-27 00:16:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Based on the operator responses to my email, I now feel comfortable that operators will not mind the move aspect of it.

First, it sucks it was a private email since that cannot be linked here for those not on the email.

I also never received a reply to my last question to eandersson and mnaser in the email thread about the actual deprecation and moving of the commands from nova-manage to nova-audit being something they care about. The responses in the email thread where not nuanced. They were basically, "yeah I like this idea, sure make it happen" with no response about my primary concern which is that I think this could be done in two stages: (1) add the new meta command and service which runs the periodics and (2) after that, gauge interest in deprecating and moving the nova-manage commands into a nova-audit command. That's my major hangup on this and why I'm likely not to +2 it in its current form.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-27 00:17:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-27 00:23:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Restoring as a multi-person effort.

And if this is a multi-person effort now, and you're going to be co-author, shouldn't you abstain from +2ing what would effectively be, at least in part, your own spec?"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-27 00:32:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > Based on the operator responses to my email, I now feel
 > comfortable that operators will not mind the move aspect of it.
 > 
 > First, it sucks it was a private email since that cannot be linked
 > here for those not on the email.

It does, but no one replied to the mail to the public list [1] earlier so I thought I'd try a different avenue. I sent that email for myself because I was overthinking it and worried if operators would be upset about commands moving. I didn't want to spam everyone for a personal sanity check.

I was +2 save for that specific worry and my worry was alleviated by me asking for a sanity check directly.

 > I also never received a reply to my last question to eandersson and
 > mnaser in the email thread about the actual deprecation and moving
 > of the commands from nova-manage to nova-audit being something they
 > care about. The responses in the email thread where not nuanced.
 > They were basically, "yeah I like this idea, sure make it happen"
 > with no response about my primary concern which is that I think
 > this could be done in two stages: (1) add the new meta command and
 > service which runs the periodics and (2) after that, gauge interest
 > in deprecating and moving the nova-manage commands into a
 > nova-audit command. That's my major hangup on this and why I'm
 > likely not to +2 it in its current form.

I understand. I thought about it more and ended up agreeing with Dan that it should be done together as a package deal. I think it would be less confusing and less ugly to leave things separated in an interim step. Just MHO.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010595.html'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-27 00:39:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

> > Restoring as a multi-person effort.
 > 
 > And if this is a multi-person effort now, and you're going to be
 > co-author, shouldn't you abstain from +2ing what would effectively
 > be, at least in part, your own spec?

I wasn't thinking about it that way because this was not my idea, but I see your point if I am going to have to help with this. I'll downgrade to a +1 and upgrade back to +2 if Dan decides he's willing to hammer out the entire thing during the holiday lull."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-27 00:40:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-27 00:52:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I understand. I thought about it more and ended up agreeing with
 > Dan that it should be done together as a package deal. I think it
 > would be less confusing and less ugly to leave things separated in
 > an interim step. Just MHO.

Sigh,

*less confusing and less ugly *THAN* to leave things separated in an interim step'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-27 01:36:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > Based on the operator responses to my email, I now feel
 > comfortable that operators will not mind the move aspect of it.
 > 
 > First, it sucks it was a private email since that cannot be linked
 > here for those not on the email.
 > 
 > I also never received a reply to my last question to eandersson and
 > mnaser in the email thread about the actual deprecation and moving
 > of the commands from nova-manage to nova-audit being something they
 > care about. The responses in the email thread where not nuanced.
 > They were basically, "yeah I like this idea, sure make it happen"
 > with no response about my primary concern which is that I think
 > this could be done in two stages: (1) add the new meta command and
 > service which runs the periodics and (2) after that, gauge interest
 > in deprecating and moving the nova-manage commands into a
 > nova-audit command. That's my major hangup on this and why I'm
 > likely not to +2 it in its current form.

I agree with the meta service and command.  I agree with the idea that this could be an always-running service *or* a one-time thing (depending on how you execute it).

nova-manage being the entry point to that codebase, or nova-audit doesn't matter to me personally as a deployer.  It would a trivial thing to change the call to the command

Personally, I'd skip with all of those commands and go to running the service with the "fix things pls" mode on.'}, {'account_id': 9452, 'date': '2019-11-27 02:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

> > Deprecating nova-manage makes sense to me. I'd rather have this
 > in a service repairing everything on the fly.
 > 
 > The spec isn't proposing that certain nova-manage commands would
 > just be deprecated and eventually removed and replaced by this
 > nova-audit service. It's saying the nova-manage commands in
 > question would be deprecated and moved to the nova-audit command
 > which could also be run in daemon mode, but the commands themselves
 > wouldn't be removed so you still have a way to run them on-demand
 > as needed.

Understood, what I had intended to say was "deprecating *these from* nova-manage [...] i'd rather have *these* running in a service repairing everything on the fly. 

I think that in general we'd be happy to just run this with 'fix the problems so things work' mode enabled. To Mohammed's point, changing our wrapper scripts from nova-manage to nova-audit would be trivial.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-27 03:41:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8064, 'date': '2020-01-08 07:44:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

As an operator, I too would love a daemon that fixes things in the background, and an interactive mode where it tells me things it can't fix. (like fsck)

Some questions:

1) How will this work for cross project inconsistency - cinder bdm comes to mind. Also if placement is spun out from nova?

2) Any possibility that the design can accept plugins? It will be useful for custom audits and sharing between ops (e.g. something that only happens for a small number of clouds, but affect a large number of instances so writing code for it is necessary but might not get accepted upstream)

Thanks for taking this up; this is a big challenge."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-30 23:02:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2020-01-31 08:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-02-13 18:41:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-02-13 19:02:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

Removing my vote since I would be working on this if it gets approved.

I'm also avoiding updating the commit message because I don't want to lose all of the +1 votes from operators."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2020-02-14 09:04:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

So my +2 here is for the concept. Sounds brillant. Agreed the deamon sounds like an easy way to make sure we throttle things appropriately.

I think deprecating the crazy long list of "do thing" nova-manage stuff sounds like a decent tidy up, and given all the +1 form the folks who keep us honest about that kind of thing, then cool.

While the detail of all the things we are adding seems sound, I clearly haven't spent quite a long reviewing all that, but it feels like code review is a better place to argue about those details, and it become clear what the right way forward really is for each of those things.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2020-02-14 09:55:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(4 comments)

I honestly feel that the path for implementing this spec is now clear. We could still have some open questions about details but I'm all good deferring those detail discussions during the implementation phase since I don't think it would be more than just some implementation concerns."}]

commit_message:
Improve handle_delete/check_delete_complete for resources

If resource is not found in handle_delete, no need to get
the resource again in check_delete_complete.

Change-Id: Ib2ac05e4f89fe8eb159e4cb871828ce07bd03089

stop testing it. Leap 15.0 should be sufficient.

commit_message:
Set show_diff to false for auth_file

We should not show changes in output since
the password might be leaked there.

I will add a follow-up patch later in master
that cleans up testing and etc.

We need to backport this to all versions.

Change-Id: Ief909c8303d7d29dcd0c19ee4cb4974667eadbcb
(cherry picked from commit 1c072a304ea9a5f791223d617ed2a49754690903)

commit_message:
Set show_diff to false for auth_file

We should not show changes in output since
the password might be leaked there.

I will add a follow-up patch later in master
that cleans up testing and etc.

We need to backport this to all versions.

Change-Id: Ief909c8303d7d29dcd0c19ee4cb4974667eadbcb
(cherry picked from commit 1c072a304ea9a5f791223d617ed2a49754690903)

"ncat" binary as root and inside a namespace.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/#/q/If8cf47a01dc353734ad07ca6cd4db7bec6c90fb6

commit_message:
Add "ncat" rootwrap filter for debug

In [1], new tests to check "ncat" tool were added. The missing piece
of this patch was to add a new rootwrap filter to allow to execute
"ncat" binary as root and inside a namespace.

Closes-Bug: #1862927

[1]https://review.opendev.org/#/q/If8cf47a01dc353734ad07ca6cd4db7bec6c90fb6

Change-Id: I8e8e5cd8c4027cce58c7073002120d14f251463d

subject: [S2007072] Enables case insensitive user name search.
messages:
[{'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-06 20:33:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-07 15:42:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-07 17:06:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-07 19:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-07 19:43:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-07 21:46:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-08 13:40:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-08 15:56:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-09 15:45:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-09 15:48:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-09 15:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2020-01-09 19:09:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

I'm not sure I like the idea of this; nothing against this implementation, but I don't like the concept of fuzzy searching keystone database.

If this was something Keystone provided that Heat tapped into, I can see it being viable, but this looks like a kludge in Heat to cover up a shortcoming of a badly designed deployment somewhere.

Would like to see other comments from other folks, but for me the concept behind this is dangerous, and if justified, I doubt Heat is the right place for this."}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-09 19:31:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Per comment 1.a in the user story: https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2007072. We need similar case insensitive search ability in heat keystone client, we can either implement in heat keystone cli (that's is the only option, since user name comparision is in heat code base) or update heat code base to use openstack cli which would be a major change."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-09 21:42:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)

I found the Keystone docs on this:

https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html

tl;dr it depends on the backend (yikes!).

OSC just calls the keystoneclient lib, so I think there is actually a way to use to same implementation that will solve all of our problems.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-13 16:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Thanks for the comment, will switch to osc/keystoneclient native ability to get case insensitive users.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-01-14 16:23:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I do not see self.client().client.users.find() in keystone client. I see get and list only which we already use: https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/v3/users.py

osc_lib uses manager class, we don't expose the manager class in keystoneclient. 

Could you give some more idea on how to use ocs_lib in heat keystoneclient? I'm still checking..."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-17 03:56:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> I do not see self.client().client.users.find() in keystone client. I see get and list only which we already use: https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/v3/users.py

It's implemented here: https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/base.py#L482-L509

And inherited here: https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/v3/users.py#L35"}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-03 16:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-03 17:31:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-02-03 19:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Unit tests needs to be updated, but functional tests are passing (grenade looks to be broken by Neutron).'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-03 22:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 30495, 'date': '2020-02-04 14:42:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-02-04 14:49:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-07 18:17:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-07 18:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-07 18:23:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 30495, 'date': '2020-02-07 19:25:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-02-10 15:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2

recheck neutron grenade'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2020-02-13 16:41:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-13 16:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-13 16:56:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30515, 'date': '2020-02-13 19:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

recheck neutron grenade'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2020-02-14 06:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks Sam:)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-06 20:33:31.000000000', 'message': '[S2007072] Enables case insensitive user name search.

Task: 37963

If heat templates use keystone user name in a case different
from the case in which the user name is stored in keystone DB
Heat stack creates fails. This change adds an option to heat
engine to enable case insensitive user name search.

Change-Id: I8e5cb027beebce39921d336fb3845125b0efc5bc

commit_message:
[S2007072] Enables case insensitive user name search.

Task: 37963

If heat templates use keystone user name in a case different
from the case in which the user name is stored in keystone DB
Heat stack creates fails. This change adds an option to heat
engine to enable case insensitive user name search.

Change-Id: I8e5cb027beebce39921d336fb3845125b0efc5bc

Remove reference to deprecated novaclient.exception

The ``ConnectionRefused`` exception was removed from
``python-novaclient`` in the following commit:
81ec72ecf8c32b409afedc60e013f9b4c47d5bae

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Tempest is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support. Last Tempest version officially supported
for py2.7 is 23.0.0.

Now onwards, Tempest will test all stable branch with py3 jobs.
tempest-full and other py2 version of jobs definition are kept
for stable branch gate.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I75868d5c9b6630fe78958ff89e58a0aced09a6b3

commit_message:
Revert "Remove all example configs for deprecated registry"

This reverts commit 2a28696de9e18a3866631507739944ceb3460872.

Devstack still references a number of these files; revert until
devstack incorporates removal.

Change-Id: I1e90ceee1f87291668e447f180f37bb809763836

commit_message:
Remove mistral from the scale_down deploy workflow

This change removes all of mistral from the scale_down function by calling the
required functions directly. To enable this process, the deploy method for
"config_download" from the deployment workflow has been updated so that it is
now able to be reused.

Task: 38422
Story: 2007212

Change-Id: Ie7a1ed7e4bed829badd03bb9e177318b995618dd
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-10 16:57:33.000000000', 'message': '[OVS] Handle added/removed ports in the same polling iteration

The OVS agent processes the port events in a polling loop. It could
happen (and more frequently in a loaded OVS agent) that the "removed"
and "added" events can happen in the same polling iteration. Because
of this, the same port is detected as "removed" and "added".

When the virtual machine is restarted, the port event sequence is
"removed" and then "added". When both events are captured in the same
iteration, the port is already present in the bridge and the port is
discharted from the "removed" list.

Because the port was removed first and the added, the QoS policies do
not apply anymore (QoS and Queue registers, OF rules). If the QoS
policy does not change, the QoS agent driver will detect it and won't
call the QoS driver methods (based on the OVS agent QoS cache, storing
port and QoS rules). This will lead to an unconfigured port.

This patch solves this issue by detecting this double event and
registering it as "removed_and_added". When the "added" port is
handled, the QoS deletion method is called first (if needed) to remove
the unneded artifacts (OVS registers, OF rules) and remove the QoS
cache (port/QoS policy). Then the QoS policy is applied again on the
port.

NOTE: this is going to be quite difficult to be tested in a fullstack
test.

Conflicts:
      neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py

Change-Id: I51eef168fa8c18a3e4cee57c9ff86046ea9203fd
Closes-Bug: #1845161
(cherry picked from commit 50ffa5173db03b0fd0fe7264e4b2a905753f86ec)

commit_message:
[OVS] Handle added/removed ports in the same polling iteration

The OVS agent processes the port events in a polling loop. It could
happen (and more frequently in a loaded OVS agent) that the "removed"
and "added" events can happen in the same polling iteration. Because
of this, the same port is detected as "removed" and "added".

When the virtual machine is restarted, the port event sequence is
"removed" and then "added". When both events are captured in the same
iteration, the port is already present in the bridge and the port is
discharted from the "removed" list.

Because the port was removed first and the added, the QoS policies do
not apply anymore (QoS and Queue registers, OF rules). If the QoS
policy does not change, the QoS agent driver will detect it and won't
call the QoS driver methods (based on the OVS agent QoS cache, storing
port and QoS rules). This will lead to an unconfigured port.

This patch solves this issue by detecting this double event and
registering it as "removed_and_added". When the "added" port is
handled, the QoS deletion method is called first (if needed) to remove
the unneded artifacts (OVS registers, OF rules) and remove the QoS
cache (port/QoS policy). Then the QoS policy is applied again on the
port.

NOTE: this is going to be quite difficult to be tested in a fullstack
test.

Conflicts:
      neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py

Change-Id: I51eef168fa8c18a3e4cee57c9ff86046ea9203fd
Closes-Bug: #1845161
(cherry picked from commit 50ffa5173db03b0fd0fe7264e4b2a905753f86ec)

messages: [{'account_id': 31004, 'date': '2020-02-07 14:41:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 31004, 'date': '2020-02-10 09:59:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2020-02-10 20:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-02-14 03:31:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\n(1 comment)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-07 14:41:37.000000000', 'message': "Allow user override of beat install locations

The installation locations of elastic beats are currently hardcoded
using openstack-ansible groups and cannot readily be extended to include
non-openstack hosts. This is particularly notable with auditbeat,
packetbeat and filebeat, which directly use the OSA 'hosts' group, and
metricbeat, which uses 'all'.

This commit allows these choices to be overrided by defining groups
named filebeat, metricbeat etc, with naming conventions as with the elk
integration inventory. Using integration inventories, one can include
the OSA groups within the override to extend the deployment. The defaults
are unchanged, with the exception of Metricbeat, which is now by default
deployed to the OSA groups 'hosts' and 'all_containers' instead of 'all'.

Change-Id: Ie39fc10f5749c9636c890a0417fc532f77562144
"}, {'created': '2020-02-10 09:59:18.000000000', 'message': "Allow user override of beat install locations

The installation locations of elastic beats are currently hardcoded
using openstack-ansible groups and cannot readily be extended to include
non-openstack hosts. This is particularly notable with auditbeat,
packetbeat and filebeat, which directly use the OSA 'hosts' group, and
metricbeat, which uses 'all'.

This commit allows these choices to be overrided by defining groups
named filebeat, metricbeat etc, with naming conventions as with the elk
integration inventory. Using integration inventories, one can include
the OSA groups within the override to extend the deployment. The defaults
are unchanged, with the exception of Metricbeat, which is now by default
deployed to the OSA groups 'hosts' and 'all_containers' instead of 'all'.

Change-Id: Ie39fc10f5749c9636c890a0417fc532f77562144
"}]
commit_message:
Allow user override of beat install locations

The installation locations of elastic beats are currently hardcoded
using openstack-ansible groups and cannot readily be extended to include
non-openstack hosts. This is particularly notable with auditbeat,
packetbeat and filebeat, which directly use the OSA 'hosts' group, and
metricbeat, which uses 'all'.

This commit allows these choices to be overrided by defining groups
named filebeat, metricbeat etc, with naming conventions as with the elk
integration inventory. Using integration inventories, one can include
the OSA groups within the override to extend the deployment. The defaults
are unchanged, with the exception of Metricbeat, which is now by default
deployed to the OSA groups 'hosts' and 'all_containers' instead of 'all'.

Change-Id: Ie39fc10f5749c9636c890a0417fc532f77562144

commit_message:
keystone/ldap: add missing cloud name

... or Ansible will use the default "openstack" cloud, which isn't good.
We need to create domains in the actual overcloud.

Change-Id: I129d7355364c87c40f51372b402620790a31ec81

commit_message:
Remove explicit compress of log files

Explicit compress is not needed post [1], explicit
compress is making log files not browsable.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-January/011875.html

Change-Id: I480391556e809b9d2f2bc693453f0fff2be9b0ab

Unable to freeze job graph: Decryption failed.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2020-02-13 21:23:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2020-02-13 23:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2020-02-14 02:35:24.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

For reference; this largely works for virtualenv -- we can provide the latest virtualenv inside a venv to maintain backwards compatability

pip is a different story.  if you install pip in a venv, you *can* make it break out of that venv to install into the system with something like "--prefix=/usr/local" ... but then on debian for example you hit the problem that it installs into "site-packages" not "dist-packages" so nothing can find whatever is installed.  

it starts getting crazy, and this is all already crazy enough'}]

commit_message:
[wip] pip-and-virtualenv : home everything in environments

* home the latest versions of pip & virtualenv in their own venv's
* use some small wrappers to make sure the tools in the extant paths
  act the same as if we'd installed these globally

Change-Id: I3b8d48402ca4fc438ca672e35d46709e496b3297

subject: Flush confirmation messages
messages: [{'account_id': 27224, 'date': '2020-01-27 23:15:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2020-02-12 23:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nYes please, this confused the heck out of me for a while, and is quite frustrating sometimes. :D'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2020-02-14 02:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2020-02-14 02:05:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-27 23:15:32.000000000', 'message': "Flush confirmation messages

Confirmation messages for cluster, profile, policy, receiver and node
deletions are printed using sys.stdout.write.  However sys.stdout.write
output is line-buffered [1].  Since the confirmation message does not
contain a newline, the message may not appear in the user's terminal.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/sys.html#sys.stdout

Change-Id: I829811df362bcfd7d074523958d2aa5232da6f09
Closes-Bug: 1861042
"}]
commit_message:
Flush confirmation messages

Confirmation messages for cluster, profile, policy, receiver and node
deletions are printed using sys.stdout.write.  However sys.stdout.write
output is line-buffered [1].  Since the confirmation message does not
contain a newline, the message may not appear in the user's terminal.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/sys.html#sys.stdout

Change-Id: I829811df362bcfd7d074523958d2aa5232da6f09
Closes-Bug: 1861042

commit_message:
Remove json_error callback

This change removes the json_error callback plugin. This plugin does not work, as seen in the
logs:

    [WARNING]: Failure using method (v2_playbook_on_stats) in callback plugin (<ans
    ible.plugins.callback./usr/share/ansible/plugins/callback/json_error.CallbackMo
    dule object at 0x7f6ee2270dd0>): [Errno 13] Permission denied: 'ansible-
    errors.json'

Given this plugin has no value, due to it being broken for a long time, we're removing it which
will stop the warning being raised in our ansible output.

* The test_json_error_callback role has also been removed, given this no longer serves any purpose.
* The molecule test layout has been updated so that we're no longer running this test.

Change-Id: I76cd51df4ff26b22f3d9b590ceded848581d4c3d
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 16:55:51.000000000', 'message': 'Use domain variable instead of generic resource data

When migrating from puppet to ansible, some variables were changed to be
more specific. Included in this was the variable for domain creation,
which is used when deploying keystone with domain-specific backend
template (e.g., backing keystone domains to LDAP servers):

  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701026/19

Recently, domain information was put into
batched_tripleo_keystone_resources_domains instead of
batched_tripleo_keystone_resources_data. This commit updates the domain
plays to use the new variable. Not doing this will result in an error
like the following on the undercloud:

  fatal: [undercloud]: FAILED! => {"msg": "'batched_tripleo_keystone_resources_data' is undefined"}

Change-Id: I33530e6e3f7ac156e07545b0455c99bb7d2274ef
(cherry picked from commit e970807e68fa8a373f685571b6bd8f7e755a2752)
'}]
commit_message:
Use domain variable instead of generic resource data

When migrating from puppet to ansible, some variables were changed to be
more specific. Included in this was the variable for domain creation,
which is used when deploying keystone with domain-specific backend
template (e.g., backing keystone domains to LDAP servers):

  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701026/19

Recently, domain information was put into
batched_tripleo_keystone_resources_domains instead of
batched_tripleo_keystone_resources_data. This commit updates the domain
plays to use the new variable. Not doing this will result in an error
like the following on the undercloud:

  fatal: [undercloud]: FAILED! => {"msg": "'batched_tripleo_keystone_resources_data' is undefined"}

Change-Id: I33530e6e3f7ac156e07545b0455c99bb7d2274ef
(cherry picked from commit e970807e68fa8a373f685571b6bd8f7e755a2752)

subject: tripleo-keystone-resources: hide logs for resources with passwords

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 16:54:45.000000000', 'message': "tripleo-keystone-resources: hide logs for resources with passwords

Hide the logs for the modules where we use data that shows the password when
creating a user, this isn't good for the security.
Let's hide it with no_log: true.

Change-Id: Icc80c239f507a1a4e50298345a94aba4fabed80d
(cherry picked from commit 6f77ee5e7bba47da6592e617fa4597e8520288cc)
"}]
commit_message:
tripleo-keystone-resources: hide logs for resources with passwords

Hide the logs for the modules where we use data that shows the password when
creating a user, this isn't good for the security.
Let's hide it with no_log: true.

Change-Id: Icc80c239f507a1a4e50298345a94aba4fabed80d
(cherry picked from commit 6f77ee5e7bba47da6592e617fa4597e8520288cc)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-12 17:22:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add RootStackName parameter on stack update

The task to add the RootStackName parameter to plan-environment.yaml in
the plan was only in the create_deployment_plan workflow. This patch
also adds it to the update_deployment_plan workflow so that the

commit_message:
Add RootStackName parameter on stack update

The task to add the RootStackName parameter to plan-environment.yaml in
the plan was only in the create_deployment_plan workflow. This patch
also adds it to the update_deployment_plan workflow so that the
parameter will be present in the environment for both stack create and
update.

Change-Id: I560eaff21c22d2ab70c657b35a3d43a76003e6ba
Closes-Bug: #1853362
(cherry picked from commit 07444eed0736ceab8af6ca7b37877223cfc4ade7)

subject: Replace '' by [] when a bind mount isn't needed
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 10969, 'name': 'Shnaidman Sagi (Sergey)', 'display_name': 'Shnaidman Sagi', 'email': 'sshnaidm@redhat.com', 'username': 'sergsh'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-10 17:02:01.000000000', 'message': 'Replace '' by [] when a bind mount isn't needed

To avoid empty volumes like:

{
  (...)
  "volumes": [
    "/etc/puppet:/etc/puppet:ro",
    (...)
    "",
    ""
  ],
}

Replace '' by [], so heat won't create an item in the list.
It helps to have idempotent containers, since podman_container module
will compare the list of volumes that is given in parameters (containing
the empty entries) vs the list of volumes actually in podman inspect.
Replacing to [] clears out empty volumes and makes these containers
idempotent when podman_container module is used to deploy containers.

Change-Id: I228b01009e7d9980bee5480778dbc88b9e226297
(cherry picked from commit 98118b6294b750e3b344ff7fc74492ac229bd866)
'}]
commit_message:
Replace '' by [] when a bind mount isn't needed

To avoid empty volumes like:

{
  (...)
  "volumes": [
    "/etc/puppet:/etc/puppet:ro",
    (...)
    "",
    ""
  ],
}

Replace '' by [], so heat won't create an item in the list.
It helps to have idempotent containers, since podman_container module
will compare the list of volumes that is given in parameters (containing
the empty entries) vs the list of volumes actually in podman inspect.
Replacing to [] clears out empty volumes and makes these containers
idempotent when podman_container module is used to deploy containers.

Change-Id: I228b01009e7d9980bee5480778dbc88b9e226297
(cherry picked from commit 98118b6294b750e3b344ff7fc74492ac229bd866)

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary slash volume maps

When podman parses such volume map it removes the slash
automatically and shows in inspection volumes w/o slash.
When comparing configurations it turns to be a difference and
it breaks idempotency of containers, causing them to be recreated.

Change-Id: Ifdebecc8c7975b6f5cfefb14b0133be247b7abf0
(cherry picked from commit 016f7c600242e1a1c7930eb41b762aed3a98701f)

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

coverage2sql is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I7e523bff1144d827dd1377c00d4a51512e265a85

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-22 16:15:52.000000000', 'message': 'Fix generation of TRIPLEO_CONFIG_HASH for services

A container gets a config hash if one of its bind mount references
/var/lib/config-data/(puppet-generated)?/service. That hash is
created/managed by container-puppet.py and stored in
/var/lib/config-data/(puppet-generated)?/service.md5sum

Currently, the parsing of bind-mount is broken so container-puppet.py
never associates or regenerates config hashes for containers. Fix
the parsing to make sure that any bind-mounts starting with
/var/lib/config-data always resolve to the right md5sum file.

Change-Id: I7ad50d62e6177f109f513c4c11f611be60e570f2
Closes-Bug: #1860364
(cherry picked from commit a5ffef4a40dbfb48926dfd6b0057547343b9a082)

commit_message:
Fix generation of TRIPLEO_CONFIG_HASH for services

A container gets a config hash if one of its bind mount references
/var/lib/config-data/(puppet-generated)?/service. That hash is
created/managed by container-puppet.py and stored in
/var/lib/config-data/(puppet-generated)?/service.md5sum

Currently, the parsing of bind-mount is broken so container-puppet.py
never associates or regenerates config hashes for containers. Fix
the parsing to make sure that any bind-mounts starting with
/var/lib/config-data always resolve to the right md5sum file.

Change-Id: I7ad50d62e6177f109f513c4c11f611be60e570f2
Closes-Bug: #1860364
(cherry picked from commit a5ffef4a40dbfb48926dfd6b0057547343b9a082)

[{'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-02-06 15:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2020-02-06 15:11:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build failed.

- pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered finger://d0fe4b8af32b/d69cf2cbce86400c9d7b178fffeaf96e : RETRY_LIMIT in 7s'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-02-06 15:22:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We need a more thorough fix for this, but this is something that operators can do immediately without upgrading.  BTW, this issue only arises in Train+.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2020-02-06 16:27:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

LGTM, I had totally forgotten about this configurable in the context of bug #1852106. This is definitely something that we want to do but I'd still like to see changes on the Glance side to avoid the removal of a key from duplicated images."}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2020-02-06 17:36:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/706298/1 : FAILURE in 2h 28m 01s'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2020-02-06 18:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-40813 : FAILURE in 2h 51m 01s'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-02-06 19:28:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Lee: agree that we need to build in some safeguards around this is both Glance and Cinder (Cinder doesn't check before deletion, either, because this situation should never happen).  I'm not sure whether it would be better to check up-front (not allow a duplicate to be set) or on deletion, as you suggested.

It's a slightly different bug, but I think there's some room for a change to Nova, too -- since we currently don't support booting directly from this type of image, and since this type of image will have the cinder_encryption_key_id as an image property, Nova could error out on this boot request instead of going ahead and creating an active instance that is unusable.  Does that sound like something worth following up on?"}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2020-02-07 11:00:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> @Lee: agree that we need to build in some safeguards around this is
 > both Glance and Cinder (Cinder doesn't check before deletion,
 > either, because this situation should never happen).  I'm not sure
 > whether it would be better to check up-front (not allow a duplicate
 > to be set) or on deletion, as you suggested.

I think on deletion for Glance as that would allow Cinder to upload multiple copies of the same volume as backups?

 > It's a slightly different bug, but I think there's some room for a
 > change to Nova, too -- since we currently don't support booting
 > directly from this type of image, and since this type of image will
 > have the cinder_encryption_key_id as an image property, Nova could
 > error out on this boot request instead of going ahead and creating
 > an active instance that is unusable.  Does that sound like
 > something worth following up on?

The issue there is that we can't guarantee that out of tree virt drivers don't already support this.

We could make the behaviour configurable I guess and reject requests until we wire up some kind of support."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-02-10 16:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Agreed in IRC [1] to:
- Block ops that snapshot encrypted images at the API level;
- Maintain a list of "never-to-be-inherited" properties and always pop them off the image, regardless of their presence on non_inheritable_image_properties, in the spirit of [2].

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2020-02-10.log.html#t2020-02-10T15:29:09
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706888/'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-02-13 23:11:17.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Superseded by https://review.opendev.org/#/c/707738/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-06 15:07:47.000000000', 'message': 'Do not inherit cinder_ image properties

In the unlikely event that an end user creates an image from an
active yet unusable instance that was booted from a glance image
of an encrypted cinder volume, deleting such an image will result
in deletion of the encryption key for the original image, thereby
leading to data loss.  This can be prevented by blocking inheritance
of the two cinder_encryption_key_* properties.

Change-Id: If20071d8e7ce6c0a4efd14a7fa6d9adef3c9fba6
Partial-bug: #1852106
'}]
commit_message:
Do not inherit cinder_ image properties

In the unlikely event that an end user creates an image from an
active yet unusable instance that was booted from a glance image
of an encrypted cinder volume, deleting such an image will result
in deletion of the encryption key for the original image, thereby
leading to data loss.  This can be prevented by blocking inheritance
of the two cinder_encryption_key_* properties.

Change-Id: If20071d8e7ce6c0a4efd14a7fa6d9adef3c9fba6
Partial-bug: #1852106

commit_message:
Fix Octavia certificate file path and content

Certificate files were being created in a wrong path and with invalid
content. The bug was caused because Ansible variables were not being
quoted, and as so Ansible assumed plain text instead.

Closes-Bug: #1830190

Change-Id: Ie576537d77b57927d430f20b274d1cb5d351241e
(cherry picked from commit 4de9f78b291e2a1f0311aa4c705daba08322cc7e)
(cherry picked from commit 71c099f2092e77b35099eee1e1e763283549c7ad)

[{'created': '2020-02-12 14:49:36.000000000', 'message': 'Execute healthchecks as root

Some containers doesn't have the "default" user set to root (which is
good). This lead to healthcheck_port() function to return a message

commit_message:
Execute healthchecks as root

Some containers doesn't have the "default" user set to root (which is
good). This lead to healthcheck_port() function to return a message
because the non-root user isn't allowed to call "ss" command as itself.

Ensuring we're running the healthchecks as root will also allow to stop
duplicating some commands, making them faster and smaller for the
system.

This was discovered and discussed on Red Hat bugzilla first, then ported
to Launchpad.

Change-Id: I2e49d4dd5b385237f4f79929c70365424f6fa22d
Closes-Bug: 1860569
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1778881
(cherry picked from commit 3012fe75aa1385896e45abf797e6adb2ee5c72ae)
(cherry picked from commit 592dab7a847140171e534bba395fcb1be42ce44e)

content. The bug was caused because Ansible variables were not being
quoted, and as so Ansible assumed plain text instead.

Closes-Bug: #1830190

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-07 14:47:25.000000000', 'message': "Update ro excludes

When container-puppet.sh (or docker-puppet.sh) runs, we always bind
mount in certain directories and files. However if these files change
while we're running the puppet execution externally on the host, they
end up being copied to our puppet-generated path. This path is copied
into the container when kolla starts up. Because we re-mount these same
paths in the end container as read-only, kolla will try and update the
read-only mount which errors. This change updates our rsync excludes to
include:

 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted
 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
 * /etc/hosts
 * /etc/localtime

Conflicts:
        common/container-puppet.sh

Change-Id: I858a7b8745688c6271b01795460ab4adbf3f2be5
Closes-Bug: #1860607
(cherry picked from commit 36ea0148e8b2ed30fb0a03fe6f812fd00657924b)
"}]
commit_message:
Update ro excludes

When container-puppet.sh (or docker-puppet.sh) runs, we always bind
mount in certain directories and files. However if these files change
while we're running the puppet execution externally on the host, they
end up being copied to our puppet-generated path. This path is copied
into the container when kolla starts up. Because we re-mount these same
paths in the end container as read-only, kolla will try and update the
read-only mount which errors. This change updates our rsync excludes to
include:

 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted
 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
 * /etc/hosts
 * /etc/localtime

Conflicts:
        common/container-puppet.sh

Change-Id: I858a7b8745688c6271b01795460ab4adbf3f2be5
Closes-Bug: #1860607
(cherry picked from commit 36ea0148e8b2ed30fb0a03fe6f812fd00657924b)

[{'created': '2020-02-10 20:51:15.000000000', 'message': "container_puppet_config: cleanup old config files

In I98963941c9d969ab1dfd92d70f973013f84e1c25, we removed
/var/lib/docker-puppet and
/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-*.json.
Also, since the usage of container_puppet_config, there is no more
'hashed-' file when a container has a new config hash. The hash is
included in the same container config file.

The container_puppet_config module will take care of making sure no old
container startup config remains in /var/lib/tripleo-config as well as
hashed files; which aren't useful anymore and could cause troubles and
confusion.

This patch will have to be backported to stable/train.

Change-Id: I595a998196b6de386a4ff345c39fe1e6a9ed62c6

commit_message:
container_puppet_config: cleanup old config files

In I98963941c9d969ab1dfd92d70f973013f84e1c25, we removed
/var/lib/docker-puppet and
/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-*.json.
Also, since the usage of container_puppet_config, there is no more
'hashed-' file when a container has a new config hash. The hash is
included in the same container config file.

The container_puppet_config module will take care of making sure no old
container startup config remains in /var/lib/tripleo-config as well as
hashed files; which aren't useful anymore and could cause troubles and
confusion.

This patch will have to be backported to stable/train.

Change-Id: I595a998196b6de386a4ff345c39fe1e6a9ed62c6

commit_message:
Rely on u-c for venv installation

Good to rely on upper-constraints for tested versions and
to avoid upper bound in requirements.txt for projects.

Also remove not needed virtualenv_site_packages.

Also remove unnecessary relying on system ansible
to setup docker registry. Mixing system ansible
with the zuul one can create issue like Bug #1829736,
this patch handles registry setup like other zuul tasks.
Also rocky had old rpms(six-1.11.0) which are not compatible with
latest virtualenv(20.0.2)

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/707525/
Change-Id: Ib25c24078a8ee6bb6400e78999149ba186818c05

[{'created': '2019-12-06 14:24:51.000000000', 'message': "keystone: add a new parameter 'keystone_resources_managed'

keystone_resources_managed, default to
hiera('keystone_resources_managed', true) for backward compatibility,
will allow to disable Puppet to manage the keystone resources, like
endpoints, roles, services, projects and users; and instead use Ansible.

Change-Id: If4b275d3caf6098e7774d938ab89333396fbc15d
"}, {'created': '2019-12-06 18:30:25.000000000', 'message': "keystone: add a new parameter 'keystone_resources_managed'

commit_message:
keystone: add a new parameter 'keystone_resources_managed'

keystone_resources_managed, default to
hiera('keystone_resources_managed', true) for backward compatibility,
will allow to disable Puppet to manage the keystone resources, like
endpoints, roles, services, projects and users; and instead use Ansible.

Change-Id: If4b275d3caf6098e7774d938ab89333396fbc15d

commit_message:
Check return value of get subnets before iterate for ironic

With the update of openstack clients:
openstack client >= 4.0.0
neutron client >= 6.14.0
neturon lib >= 1.29.1

The command 'openstack network show ${network} -f value -c subnets'
returns '[]' instead of null string if no subnets found in the
specific network. This commit adds a check logic to avoid subsequent
command returns error by using '[]' as subnet input.

Change-Id: I7e7d5209227b0e34131b7715dbd3faa6066a94b7
Signed-off-by: Mingyuan Qi <mingyuan.qi@intel.com>

commit_message:
Add "convert_output_data" config property for YAQL

* Adding "convert_output_data" config property gives an opportunity
  to increase overal performance. If YAQL always converts an expression
  result, it often takes significant CPU time and overall workflow
  execution time increases. It is especially important when a workflow
  publishes lots of data into the context and uses big workflow
  environments. It's been tested on a very big workflow (~7k tasks)
  with a big workflow environment (~2.5mb) that often uses the YAQL
  function "<% env() %>". This function basically just returns the
  workflow environment.
* Created all necessary unit tests.
* Other style fixes.

Change-Id: Ie3169ec884ec9a0e7e50327dd03cd78dcda0a39b
