revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-06 20:25:30.000000000', 'message': '[TRAIN] Backport tripleo-systemd-wrapper (squash)

This is a combination of 4 commits.

This is the 1st commit message:

Implement tripleo-systemd-wrapper role

This patch adds a new role that will be used to manage side containers
with systemd instead of docker.socket or nsenter.  The main use case here
is Neutron, although this role is designed to work with any service.

This role will create a series of systemd files to monitor a file which
gets mounted into a container. Additionally a wrapper script is
generated which is mounted in the container that will provide the
arguments that should be used to launch new containers.

Blueprint: safe-side-containers
Change-Id: I4821b7ca0260e4dfd1717ba976cef700d160f84f
Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 699249f1790dd5646556173bf5331e7e71135ad4)

This is the commit message #2:

Remove --rm=true from sidecar container sync

Neutron uses kill-scripts which remove the container after stopping it.
If the container is launched with docker and --rm=true, the container
will automatically be cleaned up and the $(CLI) rm <container id> in the
kill script with error out because the container can't be found.

Related-Bug: #1858662
Change-Id: I3d7940cb0816adce58e0fa778469dcec95302f67
(cherry picked from commit 17d97f2618e56be606c9307551efdaadda8dff69)

This is the commit message #3:

Fix substitution in kill-script

In the kill-script there is a string "Unknown action ${SIG} for
${$CT_NAME} ${CT_ID}" which results in a "bad substitution" error, as
there is no variable named with what the contents of the CT_NAME
environment variable contains.  Remove the extraneous '$'.

Change-Id: I4c76071083bf5cb4f876d3b78c379822a8bd8db1
Fixes-Bug: #1860155
(cherry picked from commit b45d4c6d219e8e27219bca341acdfd634155d6f6)

This is the commit message #4:

Add handling of signal 15 in kill script

The reason bug #1860155 was triggered was because the kill script did
not have a stanza for handling the signal that was passed in, which is
signal 15.  Since signal 15 is unhandled, keepalived processes will
still stick around.  Add handling for signal 15.

Change-Id: I632a3ef5ec137df10f647335f6354589c2316fd0
Related-bug: #1860155
(cherry picked from commit 06dc258a28784db98e44a3de488c204f01b97613)

commit_message:
[TRAIN] Backport tripleo-systemd-wrapper (squash)

This is a combination of 4 commits.

This is the 1st commit message:

Implement tripleo-systemd-wrapper role

This patch adds a new role that will be used to manage side containers
with systemd instead of docker.socket or nsenter.  The main use case here
is Neutron, although this role is designed to work with any service.

This role will create a series of systemd files to monitor a file which
gets mounted into a container. Additionally a wrapper script is
generated which is mounted in the container that will provide the
arguments that should be used to launch new containers.

Blueprint: safe-side-containers
Change-Id: I4821b7ca0260e4dfd1717ba976cef700d160f84f
Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Emilien Macchi <emilien@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 699249f1790dd5646556173bf5331e7e71135ad4)

This is the commit message #2:

Remove --rm=true from sidecar container sync

Neutron uses kill-scripts which remove the container after stopping it.
If the container is launched with docker and --rm=true, the container
will automatically be cleaned up and the $(CLI) rm <container id> in the
kill script with error out because the container can't be found.

Related-Bug: #1858662
Change-Id: I3d7940cb0816adce58e0fa778469dcec95302f67
(cherry picked from commit 17d97f2618e56be606c9307551efdaadda8dff69)

This is the commit message #3:

Fix substitution in kill-script

In the kill-script there is a string "Unknown action ${SIG} for
${$CT_NAME} ${CT_ID}" which results in a "bad substitution" error, as
there is no variable named with what the contents of the CT_NAME
environment variable contains.  Remove the extraneous '$'.

Change-Id: I4c76071083bf5cb4f876d3b78c379822a8bd8db1
Fixes-Bug: #1860155
(cherry picked from commit b45d4c6d219e8e27219bca341acdfd634155d6f6)

This is the commit message #4:

Add handling of signal 15 in kill script

The reason bug #1860155 was triggered was because the kill script did
not have a stanza for handling the signal that was passed in, which is
signal 15.  Since signal 15 is unhandled, keepalived processes will
still stick around.  Add handling for signal 15.

Change-Id: I632a3ef5ec137df10f647335f6354589c2316fd0
Related-bug: #1860155
(cherry picked from commit 06dc258a28784db98e44a3de488c204f01b97613)

These 3 backports will save a bit of time during train deployments.

have the correct permissions.

Change-Id: I28e8017edc7e30a60288adf846da722fd6ab310e
(cherry picked from commit f2147c9974c5e4d9fec91e87a2a42a7c0b8c9d5d)

Drop legacy log folder and readme

We switched to containers a long time ago. This patch drops the
management of a /var/log/<service> directory and the creation of a
readme indicating that we've moved to containers which makes the logging
available under /var/log/containers/<service>

Change-Id: Ia4e991d5d937031ac3312f639b726a944743dd1e
(cherry picked from commit 7906fb43be72a150b5d10e0e18b21b568895b6e0)

Readd creation of /var/log/mariadb directory

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692850/ cleaned up the
legacy directories, but since then rhel8 jobs fails while
starting galera containers with error of missing
directory /var/log/mariadb, this patch adds it again.

Closes-Bug: #1851847
Change-Id: Iea081ecb3fc021fc796c93631ed6f663fd9580db
(cherry picked from commit 189d9b9211a65857cfd9191a00e9d86894af8293)
"}]
commit_message:
[train-squash] Backport legacy log folder and readme cleanups

These 3 backports will save a bit of time during train deployments.

Ensure service log folder permissions

We should ensure that the service folders are 0750. We're setting
/var/log/containers but we should also ensure the service folders also
have the correct permissions.

Change-Id: I28e8017edc7e30a60288adf846da722fd6ab310e
(cherry picked from commit f2147c9974c5e4d9fec91e87a2a42a7c0b8c9d5d)

Drop legacy log folder and readme

We switched to containers a long time ago. This patch drops the
management of a /var/log/<service> directory and the creation of a
readme indicating that we've moved to containers which makes the logging
available under /var/log/containers/<service>

Change-Id: Ia4e991d5d937031ac3312f639b726a944743dd1e
(cherry picked from commit 7906fb43be72a150b5d10e0e18b21b568895b6e0)

Readd creation of /var/log/mariadb directory

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692850/ cleaned up the
legacy directories, but since then rhel8 jobs fails while
starting galera containers with error of missing
directory /var/log/mariadb, this patch adds it again.

Closes-Bug: #1851847
Change-Id: Iea081ecb3fc021fc796c93631ed6f663fd9580db
(cherry picked from commit 189d9b9211a65857cfd9191a00e9d86894af8293)

This version officially drop the python 2 support so we release a major

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
-
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:

'}]
commit_message:
Release oslo.reports 2.0.0

This version officially drop the python 2 support so we release a major
version of oslo.reports to inform user that we break
the backward compatibility.

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
-
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I686f98758aa6371d7921fe38151909e5162ab4f5

Release oslo.limit 1.0.0

This version officially drop the python 2 support so we release a major
version of oslo.limit to inform user that we break
the backward compatibility.

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
-
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: Ib367b6109cd4fdde40c64fcab575ab55fced4b2b

[{'created': '2020-01-31 09:37:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix error logging of dev/functions

In case of failures in kayobe-overcloud-centos, the error message fails
with:
kayobe/dev/functions: line 569: LOGDIR: unbound variable

Example:
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/ce1fadc3ee6d4842a599da57a670cc18

This can be reproduced with:
set -eu

if [[ -n ${LOGDIR} ]]; then
    echo "LOGDIR set"
else
    echo "else"

Fix the error reporting with assigning an empty string to LOGDIR by

commit_message:
Fix error logging of dev/functions

In case of failures in kayobe-overcloud-centos, the error message fails
with:
kayobe/dev/functions: line 569: LOGDIR: unbound variable

Example:
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/ce1fadc3ee6d4842a599da57a670cc18

This can be reproduced with:
set -eu

if [[ -n ${LOGDIR} ]]; then
    echo "LOGDIR set"
else
    echo "else"
fi

Fix the error reporting with assigning an empty string to LOGDIR by
default.

Change-Id: Ieef73950f89e4dfb727ddc59ef2750d9b81f3c58

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-19 14:50:16.000000000', 'message': 'Work around potential double row.delete() call

The update_acls code can potentially iterate over the same ACL
twice. This temporary workaround silently ignores an attempt to
delete the same row twice in the same transaction, since that
should be safe. Ultimately, refactoring the ACL code to use sets
and possibly handle the fact that an ACL could be referenced from
multiple rows should be done.

Change-Id: I259c92116f7d3186ae5af45f1407052eb57ac0ba
Related-bug: #1857016
'}]
commit_message:
Work around potential double row.delete() call

The update_acls code can potentially iterate over the same ACL
twice. This temporary workaround silently ignores an attempt to
delete the same row twice in the same transaction, since that
should be safe. Ultimately, refactoring the ACL code to use sets
and possibly handle the fact that an ACL could be referenced from
multiple rows should be done.

Change-Id: I259c92116f7d3186ae5af45f1407052eb57ac0ba
Related-bug: #1857016

commit_message:
Add OVS ovsdb_timeout parameter

This adds the ovsdb_timeout to the ovs config
section which is the seconds that it should try
ovsdb commands before failing. [1]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/conf/agent/ovs_conf.py#L24

subject: Relax required Redfish fields handling
messages:
[{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2020-02-13 00:24:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2020-02-13 01:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2020-02-13 18:56:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- dellemc-poweredge-R740-tempest-dvsm-ironic-sushy-redfish https://stash.dellemc-community.org/logs/dellemc-poweredge-R740-tempest-dvsm-ironic-sushy-redfish/2020-02-12:18:24/707512/1/ : SUCCESS in 55m 09s'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 00:24:29.000000000', 'message': 'Relax required Redfish fields handling

Redfish defines some of the fields in its JSON schemas as
mandatory. However, some implementations ignore this requirement
and occasionally omit some required fields in the Redfish document
tree they produce.

Failing the whole Redfish interaction basing solely on the absence
of a required (bit non-essential) field makes sushy perfect, but not
exactly practical.

This patch changes to semantics of the `default` parameter in
``Field` constructor in a way that it can inhibit otherwise fatal
failure when a select of required attributes are missing.

Along this mis/feature, some non-essential fields in Redfish
message registry have been made required and defaulted effectively
making them non-required.

Change-Id: I637f11ff9ceab398077eae19db83db396356c8dc
Story: 2006641
Task: 38362
(cherry picked from commit 8440eb2826f14e579e0892ed3566f43bd86a888c)
'}]
commit_message:
Relax required Redfish fields handling

Redfish defines some of the fields in its JSON schemas as
mandatory. However, some implementations ignore this requirement
and occasionally omit some required fields in the Redfish document
tree they produce.

Failing the whole Redfish interaction basing solely on the absence
of a required (bit non-essential) field makes sushy perfect, but not
exactly practical.

This patch changes to semantics of the `default` parameter in
``Field` constructor in a way that it can inhibit otherwise fatal
failure when a select of required attributes are missing.

Along this mis/feature, some non-essential fields in Redfish
message registry have been made required and defaulted effectively
making them non-required.

Change-Id: I637f11ff9ceab398077eae19db83db396356c8dc
Story: 2006641
Task: 38362
(cherry picked from commit 8440eb2826f14e579e0892ed3566f43bd86a888c)

[{'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-11-11 07:36:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-11 19:11:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

i think this is a much better alterantive.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-11-12 12:19:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I think this would be a relatively simple change which would enable this use case without adding additional orchestration or policy to Nova.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-11-12 16:19:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(23 comments)

Hi, Ya.Wang, I agree the idea is good.  So +1 for the idea; but a soft -1 to incorporate the suggested phrasing tweaks.  Hope you don't mind. :-)"}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-11-12 16:22:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-11-12 16:32:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, one more point: I am not too fond of the very generic "no_performance_impact" name -- it hijacks the concept from all other features that can cause performance impact.

I would suggest more specific: "no_post_copy_and_auto_converge"

Better alternatives welcome.'}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-11-13 05:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-11-13 05:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(23 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-11-13 05:17:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Also, one more point: I am not too fond of the very generic
 > "no_performance_impact" name -- it hijacks the concept from all
 > other features that can cause performance impact.
 > 
 > I would suggest more specific: "no_post_copy_and_auto_converge"
 > 
 > Better alternatives welcome.

"no_post_copy_and_auto_converge" expose the hypervisor feature, and it specify libvirt feature only. The parameter in API call need generic and semanticization.

We can point the actual effect in document and cli help.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-11-13 16:48:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > Also, one more point: I am not too fond of the very generic
 > > "no_performance_impact" name -- it hijacks the concept from all
 > > other features that can cause performance impact.
 > >
 > > I would suggest more specific: "no_post_copy_and_auto_converge"
 > >
 > > Better alternatives welcome.
 > 
 > "no_post_copy_and_auto_converge" expose the hypervisor feature, and
 > it specify libvirt feature only. The parameter in API call need
 > generic and semanticization.
 > 
 > We can point the actual effect in document and cli help.

Yep, I *vastly* prefer the generic name. We can bikeshed on a better name, but I'd personally be -1 on anything which mentioned the specific features we were disabling.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-11-14 09:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

This looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-14 18:59:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

yeah no_performance_impact isn't fun but better than hypervisor specific things

bikeshedding over a better name is probably good but shouldnt hold this back"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-14 22:34:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

I have seen this.

It seems technically straightforward, so I'll upvote.

But I've got no sense of whether it's something we *should* do (i.e. whether it's important to consumers) so I'll wait for others to chime in."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-15 04:13:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Hope Matthew can +1 at here.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-15 04:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

a question how we pass that parameter down to the compute node'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-18 02:49:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-18 02:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-18 02:54:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-11-18 03:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)

Yes, as the L58,59 said, the new argument will not affect force-complete API call.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-11-21 10:55:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > > Also, one more point: I am not too fond of the very generic
 > > > "no_performance_impact" name -- it hijacks the concept from all
 > > > other features that can cause performance impact.
 > > >
 > > > I would suggest more specific: "no_post_copy_and_auto_converge"
 > > >
 > > > Better alternatives welcome.
 > >
 > > "no_post_copy_and_auto_converge" expose the hypervisor feature,
 > and
 > > it specify libvirt feature only. The parameter in API call need
 > > generic and semanticization.
 > >
 > > We can point the actual effect in document and cli help.
 > 
 > Yep, I *vastly* prefer the generic name. We can bikeshed on a
 > better name, but I'd personally be -1 on anything which mentioned
 > the specific features we were disabling.

Okay, I accept the reasonable point of not exposing "hypervisor"-specific details.  BTW, we're abusing the term "hypervisor" here to include QEMU -- "hypervisor" is strictly in the kernel/KVM area).  But I dislike using the sweeping "no_performance_impact", not least because it is a lie -- *all* migrations have an impact.

Maybe "no_migration_related_perf_impact"  (or "no_migration_perf_impact").

But calling it just "no_performance_impact" is *utterly* awful.  Sorry, not everything is "bike-shedding"; you _do_ need to take care of how you name knobs that are user-visible.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-11-21 11:03:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(+1 for the idea itself; but I strongly suggest to not take the overly-generic "no_performance_impact", and perhaps go with "no_migration_perf_impact" or some such variant.)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-11-21 11:13:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (+1 for the idea itself; but I strongly suggest to not take the
 > overly-generic "no_performance_impact", and perhaps go with
 > "no_migration_perf_impact" or some such variant.)

Ya Wang on IRC seemed amenable to: "no_live_migration_perf_impact"

... which captures the intention most accurately.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-22 06:16:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Or we should try "auto_force_complete", The default is True.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-11-22 06:46:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

When 'auto_force_complete=True' sounds like that a contract for the invoker, but some of hypervisors may don't support this. Maybe should be 'allow_auto_froce_complete'"}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-11-22 07:26:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> When 'auto_force_complete=True' sounds like that a contract for the
 > invoker, but some of hypervisors may don't support this. Maybe
 > should be 'allow_auto_froce_complete'

The purpose of the argument is to avoid performance impact, try to disable something in this API call. It should be independent of another API call(force-complete)."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-11-22 19:43:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

-1 for visibility, I guess. Main points:

Inline L66. The fact the *user* knowns whether his instance is performance-sensitive or not, but it's the *admin* doing the migration, is clunky. We're asking each operator to come up with their way for the user to communicate this performance-sensitivity to the admin, and then we give this new API to the admins. Would be better if the user could set... something (see ideas inline), and Nova can check it directly before doing a live migration. If necessary, the admin can have an API to override what the user requested.

L172 for the upgrade impact. In a rolling upgrade situation, some compute hosts may not support the new thing, it's Not Cool (TM) to accept the request, and then silently ignore the performance-sensitive param."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-11-23 05:24:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> But calling it just "no_performance_impact" is *utterly* awful. 
 > Sorry, not everything is "bike-shedding"; you _do_ need to take
 > care of how you name knobs that are user-visible.

Yes, as long as there is a migration, there will be a performance impact.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-11-23 21:08:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-11-25 05:59:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for reviewed.

 > Inline L66. The fact the *user* knowns whether his instance is
 > performance-sensitive or not, but it's the *admin* doing the
 > migration, is clunky. We're asking each operator to come up with
 > their way for the user to communicate this performance-sensitivity
 > to the admin, and then we give this new API to the admins. Would be
 > better if the user could set... something (see ideas inline), and
 > Nova can check it directly before doing a live migration. If
 > necessary, the admin can have an API to override what the user
 > requested. 

Using metadata to mark whether auto-converge/post-copy is disabled can make the process simple, but here are some problems.
1. Add property in image properties/flavor extra specs, as you said, not flexible, and will make the amount of image/flavor bloated.
2. Permission problem. User add the tag through instance metadata or other methods to decide whether the auto-converge/post-copy is disabled during live migrate. Which means, the user can indirectly operate to the virtualization layer. Generally speaking, exposing these to users is not a good choice.


 > L172 for the upgrade impact. In a rolling upgrade situation, some
 > compute hosts may not support the new thing, it's Not Cool (TM) to
 > accept the request, and then silently ignore the performance-sensitive
 > param.

Will point these in next update."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-11-27 18:38:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Using metadata to mark whether auto-converge/post-copy is disabled
 > can make the process simple, but here are some problems.
 > 1. Add property in image properties/flavor extra specs, as you
 > said, not flexible, and will make the amount of image/flavor
 > bloated.
 > 2. Permission problem. User add the tag through instance metadata
 > or other methods to decide whether the auto-converge/post-copy is
 > disabled during live migrate. Which means, the user can indirectly
 > operate to the virtualization layer. Generally speaking, exposing
 > these to users is not a good choice.

Well, the user can already operate on the virt layer indirectly by setting other image properties. We have a bunch that trigger certain XML to be generated in the libvirt driver case, for example. So that part doesn't concern me much, but all the other objections you raised are valid. I just feel like there should be a better way for the user to indicate this performance-sensitivity without going through this extra admin-only API. However, as I can't actually come up with this "better way", I can't -1 your for it. As I said, the -1 is for visibility and to stimulate discussion, not to block the spec.
 
 > > L172 for the upgrade impact. In a rolling upgrade situation, some
 > > compute hosts may not support the new thing, it's Not Cool (TM)
 > to
 > > accept the request, and then silently ignore the
 > performance-sensitive
 > > param.
 > 
 > Will point these in next update.

Fair. I understand you don't want to lose your +2 :)'}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-12-11 07:52:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > Using metadata to mark whether auto-converge/post-copy is
 > disabled
 > > can make the process simple, but here are some problems.
 > > 1. Add property in image properties/flavor extra specs, as you
 > > said, not flexible, and will make the amount of image/flavor
 > > bloated.
 > > 2. Permission problem. User add the tag through instance metadata
 > > or other methods to decide whether the auto-converge/post-copy is
 > > disabled during live migrate. Which means, the user can
 > indirectly
 > > operate to the virtualization layer. Generally speaking, exposing
 > > these to users is not a good choice.
 > 
 > Well, the user can already operate on the virt layer indirectly by
 > setting other image properties. We have a bunch that trigger
 > certain XML to be generated in the libvirt driver case, for
 > example.

Yes, but these properties are basically used as a result(e.g. set 'hw_numa_node=2', get 2 numa nodes in xml), the argument in the spec is actually affect a procedural operation, so I think place them into API is OK.

 > So that part doesn't concern me much, but all the other
 > objections you raised are valid. I just feel like there should be a
 > better way for the user to indicate this performance-sensitivity
 > without going through this extra admin-only API. However, as I
 > can't actually come up with this "better way", I can't -1 your for
 > it. As I said, the -1 is for visibility and to stimulate
 > discussion, not to block the spec.

Yes, the 'better way' is always hard to find :)
In fact, the problem is that the user wants to affect the admin operation, but it can't be directly affected by the user due to the permission. So we have to introduce an intermediate layer to let the user tell admin: 'Hey, please do the things like this'.'}, {'account_id': 27614, 'date': '2019-12-18 07:30:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29071, 'date': '2020-01-20 01:29:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

If live migration is admin operation, then why not directly expose methods and let operator choose what then want?'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-01-20 03:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-01-20 03:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-27 12:33:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

We discussed this at the last PTG and I still don't understand the point of this spec. By choosing to disable these features, you're opting for a shorter period of complete downtime rather than a longer period of degraded performance. Firstly, I'm not sure why that is better. Secondly, if it's better for some applications, why can't we just change the option on all hosts? If that's not an option, it's possible to just use host aggregates to restrict these special instances to hosts with that option. All in all, this feels like a solution to an exceptionally specific problem and if there's a really good reason to have this, it hasn't been clearly explained. Let me know if you disagree :)"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-02-13 18:18:33.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

We're at spec freeze. This has downvotes, and no update from the author in a couple of months.

To repropose for a subsequent $release please:
- Restore (or ask a nova-core to do so)
- Move the spec from specs/ussuri/ to specs/$release/
- Update the blueprint's Series Goal"}]

commit_message:
Add "live migration without performance impact" spec.

This spec proposes a way selectively disable live migration-related
features which will slow down guest performance.
It is useful for guest workloads that can't tolerate any potential
performance impact.

Change-Id: I474826eadde4ac47aa4b89e1b7fbffdfe39a4e11

commit_message:
Fix 'None' field value processing

Change [1] introduced a conditional call to Field's
"adapter" callable supposedly to work-around some OEM issues.
Sadly, the exact problem that change [1] has been trying to
solve was never explained and remains murky.

However, fix [1] has also introduced a bug which makes sushy
ignoring 'None' literals in the values. This sometimes leads
to sushy failing to operate on perfectly valid JSON documents.

This change removes most of the conditions guarding Field's
"adapter" function calls.

1. https://review.opendev.org/#/c/669963/6

Change-Id: I8d1e1691a0bb2b6315894c85569a73633d34c1cb
(cherry picked from commit 1ec13aaba2d0b9c703a2564ec588e4d6de92697b)

commit_message:
WIP: Add NodeOwnerFilter

This adds a traditional scheduler filter that will filter
ironic nodes by owner for non-admin users. The rules are:

* non-ironic nodes pass the filter as they do not apply
* admins have access to any node regardless of owning project
* non-admins only have access to the nodes their project owns
* nodes without an owner are not available to non-admins

The required version for openstacksdk gets bumped since we need
https://review.opendev.org/697179/ for the ironic virt driver.

Implements blueprint ironic-tenant-filter

Change-Id: I24e0a3dcbf956362f0b4c2d80e618993a528afb0

commit_message:
Allow overriding self.api in _build_minimal_create_server_request

Change I8c96b337f32148f8f5899c9b87af331b1fa41424 removed the api
arg from _build_minimal_create_server_request and assumes the test
has a self.api attribute but not all functional tests have a single
self.api if they are doing multi-tenant testing.

This change adds an api kwarg to the method so multi-tenant tests
can provide the per-tenant api client they want to use to create
the server.

Change-Id: I2deeae11022a01298f0275dbc2e9d247893aa814

commit_message:
Fix workaround delegation when overcloud's name is not overcloud.

tripleo-ansible-inventory use overcloud as the name of the stack by
default.  On some ci, that value may be different, this then produces
an undercloud only inventory file.

Change-Id: Ic420c0717165e01df99ad2368a23fc9fc10e71c1
Closes-Bug: #1857120
(cherry picked from commit 6483436d7d0916e5e07fa38b9041e0fd7a5dde1f)
(cherry picked from commit 1da968309d1ee8a12f1cfc4a9399eba6df4b8be8)
(cherry picked from commit 889259d861a53055e27c9aaaec7f370cd2596054)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-27 17:10:47.000000000', 'message': "Add new workarounds mechanism to apply workarounds via Ansible.

The tripleo-upgrade has a workarounds logic which allows us to
apply patches or specific modifications prior and after some of
the upgrade steps. However, if these workarouds need to be applied
in the overcloud nodes, the only way to do it was via a bash script
which would iterate over the nodes and apply the patch or perform a
change on each of the nodes.

This patch adds a new workarounds field: ansible_hosts. When this
option will be present in the workaround and it will be different
than an empty string then the workaround will be aplied via Ansible in
the nodes specified in that ansible_hosts field. This ansible_hosts
option needs to be used in combination with the command one, as
the command will be transformed in a shell Ansible task which will
be executed in the nodes passed in the ansible_hosts option.

Example:
pre_overcloud_upgrade_prepare_workarounds:
- set_root_password:
    patch: false
    basedir: ''
    id: ''
    ansible_hosts: 'overcloud'
    command: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

will turn into a set_root_password.yaml Ansible playbook under
~/ansible_workarounds:

cat ~/ansible_workarounds/set_root_password.yaml
- hosts: overcloud
  tasks:
    - name: set_root_password workaround
      shell: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

When executing the workarounds, a new bash function ansible_patch
has been included which will take care of executing the generated
Ansible playbook.

Also, an optional input parameter could be passed to workarounds.sh,
when passed, it will be taken as input for the --limit option when
executing ansible-playbook. This way, we can execute a workaround
specifically in a server, instead of running it in all of them.

Change-Id: I421ebecfc5504ac2fd225de0c4fb0cbf735bbdaf
(cherry picked from commit e582d2f30473f714260c620d5c0d3807009aa797)
(cherry picked from commit b6bac90695acecb5206227836747c7ef4f7a0ce2)
(cherry picked from commit 81035c28daf0ecd1caf3a5735afc13ffdf62d4c4)
"}]
commit_message:
Add new workarounds mechanism to apply workarounds via Ansible.

The tripleo-upgrade has a workarounds logic which allows us to
apply patches or specific modifications prior and after some of
the upgrade steps. However, if these workarouds need to be applied
in the overcloud nodes, the only way to do it was via a bash script
which would iterate over the nodes and apply the patch or perform a
change on each of the nodes.

This patch adds a new workarounds field: ansible_hosts. When this
option will be present in the workaround and it will be different
than an empty string then the workaround will be aplied via Ansible in
the nodes specified in that ansible_hosts field. This ansible_hosts
option needs to be used in combination with the command one, as
the command will be transformed in a shell Ansible task which will
be executed in the nodes passed in the ansible_hosts option.

Example:
pre_overcloud_upgrade_prepare_workarounds:
- set_root_password:
    patch: false
    basedir: ''
    id: ''
    ansible_hosts: 'overcloud'
    command: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

will turn into a set_root_password.yaml Ansible playbook under
~/ansible_workarounds:

cat ~/ansible_workarounds/set_root_password.yaml
- hosts: overcloud
  tasks:
    - name: set_root_password workaround
      shell: |
        echo redhat | passwd root --stdin

When executing the workarounds, a new bash function ansible_patch
has been included which will take care of executing the generated
Ansible playbook.

Also, an optional input parameter could be passed to workarounds.sh,
when passed, it will be taken as input for the --limit option when
executing ansible-playbook. This way, we can execute a workaround
specifically in a server, instead of running it in all of them.

Change-Id: I421ebecfc5504ac2fd225de0c4fb0cbf735bbdaf
(cherry picked from commit e582d2f30473f714260c620d5c0d3807009aa797)
(cherry picked from commit b6bac90695acecb5206227836747c7ef4f7a0ce2)
(cherry picked from commit 81035c28daf0ecd1caf3a5735afc13ffdf62d4c4)

commit_message:
Enable Ceph RGW 'account in url' option

This requires an update of the endpoint but is necessary to be able
to use public-readable containers (like temporary URLs) with RGW.

Change-Id: I6bd11bdf9c74db24c0d21fa600030e9f3b144df0
Closes-Bug: 1826894
(cherry picked from commit 7c379543ccab831da0bf4f8f4b850b534d5c5247)
(cherry picked from commit 086238e9110555f8612cb39336e9b553b5353e18)
(cherry picked from commit 3ea3c7ca92bb67696f64b0248a594d89b1fba05c)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 00:24:29.000000000', 'message': 'Handle incomplete messages in MessageRegistry

Some messges in the MessageRegistry are not having fields like
'Description' and 'Severity'. Most of the time the string in
'Message' and 'Description' fields are same. This fix proposes
to make 'Description' as not-required field and setting the
'Severity' field to default value of 'CRITICAL' if its missing
in the messages of MessageRegistry.

Example of a message in a MessageRegistry
"UpdateFailed": {
  "Message": "The update failed with a component specific error (%1).",
  "NumberOfArgs": 1,
  "ParamTypes": [
    "string"
  ],
  "Resolution": "Retry the update after remedying the component error."
}

Story: 2007216
Task: 38467
Change-Id: I3e9e2ee0867f59684c24e60772a5318801891521
(cherry picked from commit 9e12fbf109eff84ff31735a690dd010ecc4df24e)
'}]
commit_message:
Handle incomplete messages in MessageRegistry

Some messges in the MessageRegistry are not having fields like
'Description' and 'Severity'. Most of the time the string in
'Message' and 'Description' fields are same. This fix proposes
to make 'Description' as not-required field and setting the
'Severity' field to default value of 'CRITICAL' if its missing
in the messages of MessageRegistry.

Example of a message in a MessageRegistry
"UpdateFailed": {
  "Message": "The update failed with a component specific error (%1).",
  "NumberOfArgs": 1,
  "ParamTypes": [
    "string"
  ],
  "Resolution": "Retry the update after remedying the component error."
}

Story: 2007216
Task: 38467
Change-Id: I3e9e2ee0867f59684c24e60772a5318801891521
(cherry picked from commit 9e12fbf109eff84ff31735a690dd010ecc4df24e)

so where i stand on this currently is as follows.

1 make cpu_dedicated_mask work identically identically to 
cpu_realtime_mask, vcpu_pin_set, cpu_shared_set and cpu_dedicated_set

by resuing the same function cpu_realtime_mask parse_cpu_spec
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2c0cb71fb0ac0d502dc9fed24211e1ef15407b8f/nova/virt/hardware.py#L74-L133

to support ranges, lists, negation and all of the above.

second if we approve this for train it should be condtional on 1

the exsiting cpu resouces spec being complted before the oslo feature freeze this is 2 weeks before actual feature freze and haveing a full implementaion of this feature available for at least review by that date.

if we dont finish the cpu resouce tracking in placement spec before that point we should defer this to U.

if this is not implmented and integrated on top of the cpu resouce tracking spec branch by the oslo feature freeze we also should defer it to U

this gives us at least 2 weeks to finalise the impleemntaion before feature freeze.

we we dont think we can meet that deadline then i think we should defer this to U.

the -1 is for the nits stepen has raised but if we agree to this time line i would be +1 on trying to complete this as a streach goal for train.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-07-25 16:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-01-14 11:25:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Notes at here, there are a lot of discussion about whether allow to specify which instance cpu is dedicated.

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2020/nova.2020-01-09-14.00.log.html#l-69

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2020-01-09.log.html#t2020-01-09T15:02:28

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2020-01-13.log.html#t2020-01-13T14:05:10

In the end, people is looking only allow the placement-ese way (resources=PCPU:..VCPU:..). That also means only allow to specify the number of dedicated cpu for the instance.

There still should be a value 'mixed' for InstanceNUMA.cpu_policy. But won't expose in the extra spec 'hw:cpu_policy'."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-14 20:01:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> In the end, people is looking only allow the placement-ese way (resources=PCPU:..VCPU:..).

Yes.

> That also means only allow to specify the number of dedicated cpu for the instance.

Not sure what you mean by this, so let me add my understanding:

In order to get mixed CPUs, I think you should be required to be explicit and use both resources:VCPU and resources:PCPU extra specs. I don't think we should be trying to infer counts based on flavor.vcpus, emulator thread policy, etc.

And (confusingly, but it is what it is) we should require flavor.vcpus to be the total number of logical CPUs the guest will see. So that'll be resources:VCPU+resources:PCPU, possibly +1 if emulator thread policy is 'isolate'.

> There still should be a value 'mixed' for InstanceNUMA.cpu_policy. But won't expose in the extra spec 'hw:cpu_policy'.

To clarify: we can *allow* it in extra spec hw:cpu_policy (and the corresponding image meta property); I was just saying we shouldn't *require* it, since it's trivial to infer from the fact that you asked for PCPU+VCPU.

In retrospect, it seems a bit contradictory that I'm asking for explicitness in specifying VCPU+PCPU but allowing inference of cpu_policy=mixed. So I'm really not stuck on whether you make it optional or required.

However, if cpu_policy *is* specified, we're going to have to validate it. And if VCPU+PCPU resources are requested, any value *other* than 'mixed' will have to raise an error."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-01-16 05:57:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

@Eric, I think we are on the same page.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-01-19 03:02:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-01-19 06:59:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-01-19 08:56:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-27 12:14:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1

(13 comments)

It's confusing and goes against what we've been saying in the past. I assume it's dansmith I need to argue with here?"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-27 12:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

Yes; I would also like to eavesdrop. I was strongly on the side of "don't mix placement-ese and flavor-ese" and Dan and I had quite a lengthy discussion on it, which you probably want to read through so we don't have to cover the same ground again. See the IRC logs Alex linked via his top-level comment on Jan 14th.'}, {'account_id': 30209, 'date': '2020-01-28 10:14:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

commit_message:
Use PCPU and VCPU in one instance

We'd like to propose a way to create instance to
take using of PCPU and VCPU resource in one instance.

Re-proposed in U release.

Change-Id: I0c4ffe349dc9381c83c836efb4af99d072169c88

commit_message:
TEST: Fix octavia cert path if trailing slash omitted

Path separaters were missing from cert files.

NOTE: this is being submitted to queens to test issue seen in CI. This
isn't appearing elsewhere at the moment.

Change-Id: Ic95d13cf60967c4d5c329f903f396b8bd14239be

[{'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-04-05 05:34:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2019-04-05 05:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Thank you for submitting this spec.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-04-05 16:16:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)

Very happy to see this. Making this happen is on my list of stuff I'd really like to see happen in Train, so please let me know how I can help.

Part of my motivation is the way in which this finally fulfils one of the main promises of placement. Another part is that this will fix some serious disk management problems in the vmware virt driver. As I've noted within, I'll take care of the aspects of making this happen in the vmware virtdriver.

I've left several comments within. The one that has the most impact on what's described here is that that I think it would be great if we could make this as automatic as possible. That is, if at all possible: not require operators to manually identify, create and manage shared disk providers. That may not be possible in a first pass, but if it were, that would be great.

Another issue I suspect will come up as a result of this is that people will start asking about thick and thin provisioning. Placement and nova think about disk usage as always thick, but underlying shared storage systems often do something much more magic. Once shared storage starts working at all, people will then want to see it reporting more accurately. How can we do that? Does it make any sense to dynamically manage inventory in the face of storage system that are literally dynamically managing their available storage (thus inventory)?"}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-04-08 07:09:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-04-08 07:11:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For reference, the vmware update_provider_tree implementation is at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651615/'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2019-04-21 15:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(14 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-04-22 02:54:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-04-22 03:24:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

It will be a _great_ day when we finally have this working.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-05-08 08:27:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-05-08 08:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think there will be some details on the work items that will be adjusted as we get into the actual implementation of the work, but I think this gets the intent adequately.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-04 21:39:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-06-12 08:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-06-17 01:52:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-25 17:54:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I think this is missing some critical details.

Also... is anybody still asking for this? I know it was at one point probably the biggest motivator for Placement to exist, but we seem to have higher priorities right now. Given limited dev/reviewer resources, we may want to consider deferring this (again).'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-01 13:40:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

> I think this is missing some critical details.

I agree the migration scenarios need to be fleshed out a bit more.

 > Also... is anybody still asking for this? I know it was at one
 > point probably the biggest motivator for Placement to exist, but we
 > seem to have higher priorities right now. Given limited
 > dev/reviewer resources, we may want to consider deferring this
 > (again).

I can see why that might be a reasonable choice, but it is disappointing and dispiriting. What we're effectively concluding is that many (most?) people don't care about accurate use of disk in an interoperable fashion.

That certainly aligns with what's come out of discussions within vmware: The vsphere people are more interested in managing disk usage by policy, expressed via random extra specs that mean nothing outside that environment so are effectively death to interoperability.

Thus the reason to do this, if we did have time and energy, would be to push the interop agenda, of which I'm still a fan, but I think has flagged generally."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-07-02 08:17:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I have couple of questions inline.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-07-09 06:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Alternatively, you may propose your spec to the backlog per [2], or wait until the U release opens and propose it there.

Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-11-05 08:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2019-11-05 08:28:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@Tushar: Good job! This spec is now pretty well aligned with the discussion we had on the PTG. Thanks for the updates. I'm +1 on it. Not +2 yet as to 1) waiting for the others to respond 2) waiting for the placement API spec to be proposed."}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-12-09 15:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

First looking at the spec seems good, +1 for the moment until I can review more.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-11 16:36:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Tushar: Do you still working on this?'}, {'account_id': 1011, 'date': '2020-02-12 06:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> @Tushar: Do you still working on this?
Yes. Shilpa is working on the implementation part.

We are writing a spec in placement to return consolidated compute statistics for all compute node resource providers as it's done in Nova in os-hypervisors statistics API but I don't think we can implement that API in the 'U' release timeframe.

I will include details of placement RestAPI in section "Response of os-hypervisors statistics" so that it's clear what information will be returned in the os-hypervisors statistics API.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-02-13 17:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'm going to abandon this to get it off the Ussuri radar, understanding the intent to restore it for Victoria with a dependency on a TBD Placement API change.

Feel free to restore now if I've misunderstood."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-05 05:34:58.000000000', 'message': 'Allow compute nodes to use DISK_GB from shared storage RP

Allow compute node resource providers to use DISK_GB inventory
configured in a shared storage resource provider by using
aggregate relationship.

Shared resource providers are marked with a standard trait
called `MISC_SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE`. This indicates that the
provider allows its inventory to be consumed by other resource
providers associated via an aggregate link.

Change-Id: I0d64d785dc96f37cb8a7d5ac182bc14dcc6502a6

commit_message:
Allow compute nodes to use DISK_GB from shared storage RP

Allow compute node resource providers to use DISK_GB inventory
configured in a shared storage resource provider by using
aggregate relationship.

Shared resource providers are marked with a standard trait
called `MISC_SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE`. This indicates that the
provider allows its inventory to be consumed by other resource
providers associated via an aggregate link.

Blueprint: support-shared-storage-resource-provider
Change-Id: I0d64d785dc96f37cb8a7d5ac182bc14dcc6502a6

[{'created': '2020-02-05 11:20:56.000000000', 'message': 'Python 3: Use distro_python_version for dev mode

In dev mode currently the python source is mounted under python2.7
site-packages. This change fixes this to use the distro_python_version
variable to ensure dev mode works with Python 3 images.

Change-Id: Ieae3778a02f1b79023b4f1c20eff27b37f481077
Partially-Implements: blueprint python-3
(cherry picked from commit 5a786436be1ec9198b7e6e61bfcb7b37f79fa880)
'}]
commit_message:
Python 3: Use distro_python_version for dev mode

In dev mode currently the python source is mounted under python2.7
site-packages. This change fixes this to use the distro_python_version
variable to ensure dev mode works with Python 3 images.

Change-Id: Ieae3778a02f1b79023b4f1c20eff27b37f481077
Partially-Implements: blueprint python-3
(cherry picked from commit 5a786436be1ec9198b7e6e61bfcb7b37f79fa880)

commit_message:
Add Eyal's review address to Vitrage liaisons

Eyal Bar-Ilan is using a different address for reviews than
the one defined in governance. Add the review address to
the Vitrage release liaisons so that check-ptl-approval
works as intended.

Change-Id: I520d75f39ef5f458e085df3f56573af68258811f

commit_message:
CI: Fix deploy guide jobs

This fixes files relevant for them because k-a uses common files
for both docs and deploy guide.
We need this to finally get rid of Rocky mentions despite our
recent fixes to docs.

Change-Id: I46c564f3d3e53c54148186fbadfd7380c4f2fd30

subject: Make use of auth_host config and set it in openstack env
messages:
[{'account_id': 29444, 'date': '2019-11-15 23:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-12-13 12:58:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29444, 'date': '2019-12-16 21:54:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2019-12-20 11:39:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Is there a specific issue/bug that we're trying to address with the change? In later keystone versions the admin api is just a part of the main keystone API (the admin port being retained for backwards compatible reasons only).

If you wanted to ensure that the GSS service was using internal endpoints that's a bit more of an involved change."}, {'account_id': 29444, 'date': '2020-01-30 00:29:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29444, 'date': '2020-01-30 00:34:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Is there a specific issue/bug that we're trying to address with the
 > change? In later keystone versions the admin api is just a part of
 > the main keystone API (the admin port being retained for backwards
 > compatible reasons only).
 > 
 > If you wanted to ensure that the GSS service was using internal
 > endpoints that's a bit more of an involved change.

The goal as you pointed out is to make GSS use the internal endpoint. So I removed the OS_PUBLIC_AUTH_URL part and replaced service_protocol with auth_protocol.

Could you check again?"}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2020-02-13 16:42:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Alexandre, the commit message does not explain the reason for the change. Can you please create a bug with details of why the change is necessary and refer to the bug in the commit message:
Closes-Bug: #<bugnumber>
The change seems reasonable but I need to understand why we are changing it.'}]

subject: add Linaro repo with fixed libvirt
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 12:17:23.000000000', 'message': 'add Linaro repo with fixed libvirt

We want to migrate Linaro Developer Cloud to train release. But this
requires fixing libvirt to work on ThunderX1 servers [1].

1. https://bugs.linaro.org/show_bug.cgi?id=3778

This change adds repository to default ones and pin it in a way that
everything other than libvirt is ignored.

manual cherry-pick of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706705/

Change-Id: I56525cdc357e187ee6f3adae068a37cd013a9fce
'}]
commit_message:
add Linaro repo with fixed libvirt

We want to migrate Linaro Developer Cloud to train release. But this
requires fixing libvirt to work on ThunderX1 servers [1].

1. https://bugs.linaro.org/show_bug.cgi?id=3778

This change adds repository to default ones and pin it in a way that
everything other than libvirt is ignored.

manual cherry-pick of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706705/

Change-Id: I56525cdc357e187ee6f3adae068a37cd013a9fce

commit_message:
add Linaro repo with fixed libvirt

We want to migrate Linaro Developer Cloud to train release. But this
requires fixing libvirt to work on ThunderX1 servers [1].

1. https://bugs.linaro.org/show_bug.cgi?id=3778

This change adds repository to default ones and pin it in a way that
everything other than libvirt is ignored.

manual cherry-pick of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706705/

Change-Id: I56525cdc357e187ee6f3adae068a37cd013a9fce

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 11:34:43.000000000', 'message': "Fix sphinx8 script used by pep8

We wrap doc8 to register the directives we use in our documentation.
Previously the 'app' argument was passed as None, however sphinx has
started to use the argument.

This change uses a mock object since we don't need to use the
application object.

Change-Id: Id9e8d5f6d09f14d294cd493538780456f98c7dbe
"}]
commit_message:
Fix sphinx8 script used by pep8

We wrap doc8 to register the directives we use in our documentation.
Previously the 'app' argument was passed as None, however sphinx has
started to use the argument.

This change uses a mock object since we don't need to use the
application object.

Change-Id: Id9e8d5f6d09f14d294cd493538780456f98c7dbe
